verses.text: "For if," says the Scripture, "he Abraham was justified by works, he hath whereof to glory, but not toward God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:71
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:72
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:73
verses.text: ) For if he who has been vouchsafed grace maketh his boast in God, that he is loved of Him, because his sins are forgiven, he too that worketh hath whereof to boast, but not before God, as the other (for it is a proof of our excessive weakness); he who has received wisdom of God, how much more admirable is he? He glorifies God and is glorified of Him, for He says, "Them that honor Me, I will honor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:74
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:75
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:76
verses.text: )  Again, listen to him who descended from Joseph, than whom no one was wiser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:77
verses.text: "Art thou wiser," says he, "than Daniel?" (Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:78
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:79
verses.text: ) This Daniel then, when all the wise men that were in Babylon, and the astrologers moreover, the prophets, the magicians, the enchanters, yea when the whole of their wisdom was not only coming to be convicted, but to be wholly destroyed (for their being destroyed was a clear proof that they had deceived before), this Daniel coming forward, and preparing to solve the king's question, does not take the honor to himself, but first ascribes the whole to God, and says, "But as for me, O king, it is not revealed to me for any wisdom that I have beyond all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:80
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:81
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:82
verses.text: ) And "the king worshiped him, and commanded that they should offer an oblation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:83
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:84
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:85
verses.text: ) Seest thou his humility? seest thou his excellent spirit? seest thou this habit of lowliness? Listen also to the Apostles, saying at one time, "Why fasten ye your eyes on us, as though by our own power or godliness we had made this man to walk? (Acts iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:86
verses.text: ) And again, "We are men of like passions with you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:87
verses.text: (Acts xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:88
verses.text: ) Now if they thus refused the honors paid them, men who by reason of the humility and power of Christ wrought greater deeds than Christ (for He says, "He that believeth in Me shall do greater works than those that I do" (John xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:89
verses.text: , abr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:90
verses.text: )), shall not we wretched and miserable men do so, who cannot even beat away gnats, much less devils? who have not power to benefit a single man, much less the whole world, and yet think so much of ourselves that the Devil himself is not like us?  There is nothing so foreign to a Christian soul as haughtiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:91
verses.text: Haughtiness, I say, not boldness nor courage, for these are congenial.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:92
verses.text: But these are one thing, and that another; so too humility is one thing, and meanness, flattery, and adulation another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:93
verses.text: I will now, if you wish, give you examples of all these qualities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:94
verses.text: For these things which are contraries, seem in some way to be placed near together, as the tares to the wheat, and the thorns to the rose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:95
verses.text: But while babes might easily be deceived, they who are men in truth, and are skilled in spiritual husbandry, know how to separate what is really good from the bad.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:96
verses.text: Let me then lay before you examples of these qualities from the Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:97
verses.text: What is flattery, and meanness, and adulation? Ziba flattered David out of season, and falsely slandered his master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:98
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:99
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:101
verses.text: ) Much more did Ahitophel flatter Absalom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:102
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:103
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:105
verses.text: ) But David was not so, but he was humble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:106
verses.text: For the deceitful are flatterers, as when they say, "O king, live for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:107
verses.text: (Dan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:108
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:109
verses.text: ) Again, what flatterers the magicians are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:110
verses.text: We shall find much to exemplify this in the case of Paul in the Acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:111
verses.text: When he disputed with the Jews he did not flatter them, but was humble-minded (for he knew how to speak boldly), as when he says, "I, brethren, though I had done nothing against the people, or the customs of our fathers, yet was delivered prisoner from Jerusalem".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:112
verses.text: (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:113
verses.text: )  That these were the words of humility, listen how he rebukes them in what follows, "Well spake the Holy Ghost, By hearing ye shall hear, and shall in nowise understand, and seeing ye shall see, and in nowise perceive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:114
verses.text: (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:115
verses.text: ; ib.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:116
verses.text: )  Seest thou his courage? Behold also the courage of John the Baptist, which he used before Herod; when he said, "It is not lawful for thee to have thy brother Philip's wife".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:117
verses.text: (Mark vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:118
verses.text: ) This was boldness, this was courage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:119
verses.text: Not so the words of Shimei, when he said, "Begone, thou man of blood" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:120
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:121
verses.text: ), and yet he too spake with boldness; but this is not courage, but audacity, and insolence, and an unbridled tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:122
verses.text: Jezebel too reproached Jehu, when she said, "The slayer of his master" ( Kings ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:123
verses.text: ), but this was audacity, not boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:124
verses.text: Elias too reproached, but this was boldness and courage; "I do not trouble Israel, but thou and thy father's house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:125
verses.text: ( Kings xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:126
verses.text: ) Again, Elias spake with boldness to the whole people, saying, "How long will ye go lame on both your thighs?" ( Kings xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:127
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:128
verses.text: ) Thus to rebuke was boldness and courage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:129
verses.text: This too the prophets did, but that other was audacity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:130
verses.text: Would you see words both of humility and not of flattery, listen to Paul, saying, "But with me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you, or of man's judgment; yea, I judge not mine own self.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:131
verses.text: For I know nothing against myself, yet am I not hereby justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:132
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:133
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:135
verses.text: ) This is of a spirit that becomes a Christian; and again, "Dare any of you, having a matter against his neighbor, go to law before the unrighteous, and not before the saints"? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:136
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:137
verses.text: )  Would you see the flattery of the foolish Jews? listen to them, saying, "We have no king but Caesar".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:138
verses.text: (John xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:139
verses.text: ) Would you see humility? listen to Paul again, when he says, "For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:140
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:141
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:142
verses.text: ) Would you see both flattery and audacity? "Audacity" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:143
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:144
verses.text: ) in the case of Nabal, and "flattery" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:145
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:146
verses.text: ) in that of the Ziphites? For in their purpose they betrayed David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:147
verses.text: Would you see "wisdom" ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:148
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:150
verses.text: ) and not flattery, that of David, how he gat Saul into his power, and yet spared him? Would you see the flattery of those who murdered Mephibosheth, whom also David slew? In fine, and as it were in outline, to sum up all, audacity is shown when one is enraged, and insults another for no just cause, either to avenge himself, or in some unjust way is audacious; but boldness and courage are when we dare to face perils and deaths, and despise friendships and enmities for the sake of what is pleasing to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:151
verses.text: Again, flattery and meanness are when one courts another not for any right end, but hunting after some of the things of this life; but humility, when one does this for the sake of things pleasing to God, and descends from his own proper station that he may perform something great and admirable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:152
verses.text: If we know these things, happy are we if we do them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:153
verses.text: For to know them is not enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:154
verses.text: For Scripture says, "Not the hearers of a law, but the doers of a law shall be justified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:155
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:156
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:157
verses.text: ) Yea, knowledge itself condemneth, when it is without action and deeds of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 6:158
verses.text: Wherefore that we may escape the condemnation, let us follow after the practice, that we may obtain those good things that are promised to us, by the grace and love of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:2
verses.text: Philippians ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:3
verses.text: –  "Have this mind in you, which was also in Christ Jesus: who, being in the form of God, counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God, but emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men; and being found in fashion as a man, He humbled Himself, becoming obedient even unto death, yea, the death of the cross".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:4
verses.text: Our Lord Jesus Christ, when exhorting His disciples to great actions, places before them Himself, and the Father, and the Prophets, as examples; as when He says, "For thus they did unto the Prophets which were before you" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:5
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:6
verses.text: ; Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:7
verses.text: ); and again, "If they persecuted Me, they will also persecute you" (John xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:8
verses.text: ); and, "Learn of me, for I am meek" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:9
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:10
verses.text: ); and again, "Be ye merciful, as your Father which is in heaven is merciful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:11
verses.text: (Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:12
verses.text: ) This too the blessed Paul did; in exhorting them to humility, he brought forward Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:13
verses.text: And he does so not here only, but also when he discourses of love towards the poor, he speaks in this wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:14
verses.text: "For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though He was rich, yet for your sakes He became poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:15
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:16
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:17
verses.text: ) Nothing rouses a great and philosophic soul to the performance of good works, so much as learning that in this it is likened to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:18
verses.text: What encouragement is equal to this? None.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:19
verses.text: This Paul well knowing, when he would exhort them to humility, first beseeches and supplicates them, then to awe them he says, "That ye stand fast in one Spirit"; he says also, that it "is for them an evident token of perdition, but of your salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:20
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:21
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:23
verses.text: ) And last of all he says this, "Have this mind in you, which was also in Christ Jesus, who, being in the form of God, counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God, but emptied Himself, taking upon Him the form of a servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:24
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:25
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:27
verses.text: ) Attend, I entreat you, and rouse yourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:28
verses.text: For as a sharp two-edged sword, wheresoever it falls, though it be among ten thousand phalanxes, easily cuts through and destroys, because it is sharp on every side, and nought can bear its edge; so are the words of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:29
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:30
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:31
verses.text: ; Rev.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:32
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:33
verses.text: ) For by these words he has laid low the followers of Arius of Alexandria, of Paul of Samosata, of Marcellus the Galatian, of Sabellius the Libyan, of Marcion that was of Pontus, of Valentinus, of Manes, of Apollinarius of Laodicea, of Photinus, of Sophronius, and, in one word, all the heresies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:34
verses.text: Rouse yourselves then to behold so great a spectacle, so many armies falling by one stroke, lest the pleasure of such a sight should escape you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:35
verses.text: For if when chariots contend in the horse race there is nothing so pleasing as when one of them dashes against and overthrows whole chariots with their drivers, and after throwing down many with the charioteers that stood thereon, drives by alone towards the goal, and the end of the course, and amid the applause and clamor which rises on all sides to heaven, with coursers winged as it were by that joy and that applause, sweeps over the whole ground; how much greater will the pleasure be here, when by the grace of God we overthrow at once and in a body the combinations and devilish machinations of all these heresies together with their charioteers?  And if it seem good to you, we will first arrange the heresies themselves in order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:36
verses.text: Would you have them in the order of their impiety, or of their dates? In the order of time, for it is difficult to judge of the order of their impiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:37
verses.text: First then let Sabellius the Libyan come forward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:38
verses.text: What does he assert? that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, are mere names given to one Person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:39
verses.text: Marcion of Pontus says, that God the Creator of all things is not good, nor the Father of the good Christ, but another righteous one, and that he did not take flesh for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:40
verses.text: Marcellus, and Photinus, and Sophronius assert, that the Word is an energy, and that it was this energy that dwelt in Him who was of the seed of David, and not a personal substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:41
verses.text: Arius confesses indeed the Son, but only in word; he says that He is a creature, and much inferior to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:42
verses.text: And others say that He has not a soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:43
verses.text: Seest thou the chariots standing? See then their fall, how he overthrows them all together, and with a single stroke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:44
verses.text: How? "Have the same mind in you," he says, "which was in Christ Jesus, who being in the form of God, counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:45
verses.text: And Paul of Samosata has fallen, and Marcellus, and Sabellius.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:46
verses.text: For he says, "Being in the form of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:47
verses.text: If "in the form" how sayest thou, O wicked one, that He took His origin from Mary, and was not before? and how dost thou say that He was an energy? For it is written, "The form of God took the form of a servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:48
verses.text: "The form of a servant," is it the energy of a servant, or the nature of a servant? By all means, I fancy, the nature of a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:49
verses.text: Thus too the form of God, is the nature of God, and therefore not an energy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:50
verses.text: Behold also Marcellus of Galatia, Sophronius and Photinus have fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:51
verses.text: Behold Sabellius too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:52
verses.text: It is written, "He counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:53
verses.text: Now equality is not predicated, where there is but one person, for that which is equal hath somewhat to which it is equal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:54
verses.text: Seest thou not the substance of two Persons, and not empty names without things? Hearest thou not the eternal pre-existence of the Only-begotten?  Lastly, What shall we say against Arius, who asserts the Son is of a different substance? Tell me now, what means, "He took the form of a servant"? It means, He became man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:55
verses.text: Wherefore "being in the form of God," He was God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:56
verses.text: For one "form" and another "form" is named; if the one be true, the other is also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:57
verses.text: "The form of a servant" means, Man by nature, wherefore "the form of God" means, God by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:58
verses.text: And he not only bears record of this, but of His equality too, as John also doth, that he is no way inferior to the Father, for he saith, "He thought it not a thing to seize, to be equal with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:59
verses.text: Now what is their wise reasoning? Nay, say they, he proves the very contrary; for he says, that, "being in the form of God, He seized not equality with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:60
verses.text: How if He were God, how was He able "to seize upon it"? and is not this without meaning? Who would say that one, being a man, seized not on being a man? for how would any one seize on that which he is? No, say they, but he means that being a little God, He seized not upon being equal to the great God, Who was greater than He.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:61
verses.text: Is there a great and a little God? And do ye bring in the doctrines of the Greeks upon those of the Church? With them there is a great and a little God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:62
verses.text: If it be so with you, I know not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:63
verses.text: For you will find it nowhere in the Scriptures: there you will find a great God throughout, a little one nowhere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:64
verses.text: If He were little, how would he also be God? If man is not little and great, but one nature, and if that which is not of this one nature is not man, how can there be a little God and a great one?  He who is not of that nature is not God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:65
verses.text: For He is everywhere called great in Scripture; "Great is the Lord, and highly to be praised".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:66
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:67
verses.text: xlviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:68
verses.text: ) This is said of the Son also, for it always calls Him Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:69
verses.text: "Thou art great, and doest wondrous things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:70
verses.text: Thou art God alone".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:71
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:72
verses.text: lxxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:73
verses.text: ) And again, "Great is our Lord, and great is His power, and of His greatness there is no end".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:74
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:75
verses.text: cxlv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:76
verses.text: )  But the Son, he says, is little.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:77
verses.text: But it is thou that sayest this, for the Scripture says the contrary: as of the Father, so it speaks of the Son; for listen to Paul, saying, "Looking for the blessed hope, and appearing of the glory of our great God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:78
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:79
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:80
verses.text: ) But can he have said "appearing" of the Father? Nay, that he may the more convince you, he has added with reference to the appearing "of the great God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:81
verses.text: Is it then not said of the Father? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:82
verses.text: For the sequel suffers it not which says, "The appearing of our great God and Saviour Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:83
verses.text: See, the Son is great also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:84
verses.text: How then speakest thou of small and great?  Listen to the Prophet too, calling him "The Messenger of great counsel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:85
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:86
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:87
verses.text: ) "The Messenger of great counsel," is He not great Himself? "The mighty God," is He small and not great? What mean then these shameless and reckless men when they say, that being little He is a God? I repeat ofttimes what they say, that ye may the more avoid them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:88
verses.text: He being a lesser God seized not for Himself to be like the greater God! Tell me now (but think not that these words are mine), if he were little, as they say, and far inferior to the Father in power, how could He possibly have seized to Himself equality with God? For an inferior nature could not seize for himself admission into that which is great; for example, a man could not seize on becoming equal to an angel in nature; a horse could not, though he wished it, seize on being equal to a man in nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:89
verses.text: But besides all that, I will say this too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:90
verses.text: What does Paul wish to establish by this example? Surely, to lead the Philippians to humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:91
verses.text: To what purpose then did he bring forward this example? For no one who would exhort to humility speaks thus; "Be thou humble, and think less of thyself than of thine equals in honor, for such an one who is a slave has not risen against his master; do thou imitate him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:92
verses.text: This, any one would say, is not humility, but arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:93
verses.text: Learn ye what humility is, ye who have a devilish pride! What then is humility? To be lowly minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:94
verses.text: And he is lowly minded who humbles himself, not he who is lowly by necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:95
verses.text: To explain what I say; and do ye attend; he who is lowly minded, when he has it in his power to be high minded, is humble, but he who is so because he is not able to be high minded, is no longer humble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:96
verses.text: For instance, If a King subjects himself to his own officer, he is humble, for he descends from his high estate; but if an officer does so, he will not be lowly minded; for how? he has not humbled himself from any high estate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:97
verses.text: It is not possible to show humble-mindedness except it be in our power to do otherwise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:98
verses.text: For if it is necessary for us to be humble even against our will, that excellency comes not from the spirit or the will, but from necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:99
verses.text: This virtue is called humble-mindedness, because it is the humbling of the mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:100
verses.text: If he who has it not in his power to snatch at another's goods, continues in the possession of his own; should we praise him, think you, for his justice? I trow not, and why? The praise of free choice is taken away by the necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:101
verses.text: If he, who has it not in his power to usurp and be a king, remains a private citizen, should we praise him for his quietness? I trow not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:102
verses.text: The same rule applies here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:103
verses.text: For praise, O ye most senseless ones, is not given for abstaining from these things, but for the performance of good deeds; for the former is free indeed from blame, but partakes not yet of praise, while eulogy of the other is meet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:104
verses.text: Observe accordingly that Christ gives praise on this principle, when He says, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:105
verses.text: For I was an hungered, and ye gave Me meat; I was thirsty, and ye gave Me drink".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:106
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:107
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:109
verses.text: ) He did not say, Because ye have not been covetous, because ye have not robbed; these are slight things; but because "ye saw Me an hungered, and fed Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:110
verses.text: Who ever praised either his friends or his enemies in this sort? No one ever praised even Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:111
verses.text: Why say Paul? no one ever praised even a common man, as thou dost praise Christ, because he did not take that rule which was not his due.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:112
verses.text: To admire for such things as this, is to give evidence of much evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:113
verses.text: And why? because with evil men this is a matter of praise, as of one that stealeth, if he steal no more; but it is otherwise among good men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:114
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:115
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:116
verses.text: ) Because a man has not seized on a rule and an honor which was not his due, is he praiseworthy? What folly is this?  Attend, I entreat you, for the reasoning is long.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:117
verses.text: Again, who would ever exhort to humility from such grounds as this? Examples ought to be much greater than the subject, to which we are exhorting, for no one will be moved by what is foreign to the subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:118
verses.text: For instance, when Christ would lead us to do good to our enemies, He brought a great example, even that of His Father, "For He maketh His sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sendeth rain on the just and the unjust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:119
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:120
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:121
verses.text: ) When He would lead to endurance of wrong He brought an example, "Learn of Me, for I am meek and lowly in heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:122
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:123
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:124
verses.text: ) And again, "If I your Lord and Master do these things, how much more should ye"? (John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:125
verses.text: ) Seest thou how these examples are not distant, for there is no need they should be so distant, for indeed we also do these things, especially as in this case the example is not even near.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:126
verses.text: And how? If He be a servant, He is inferior, and subject to Him that is greater; but this is not lowliness of mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:127
verses.text: It was requisite to show the contrary, namely, that the greater person subjected himself to the lesser.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:128
verses.text: But since he found not this distinction in the case of God, between greater and lesser, he made at least an equality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:129
verses.text: Now if the Son were inferior, this were not a sufficient example to lead us to humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:130
verses.text: And why? because it is not humility, for the lesser not to rise against the greater, not to snatch at rule, and to be "obedient unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:131
verses.text: Again, consider what he says after the example, "In lowliness of mind, each counting other better than themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:132
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:133
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:134
verses.text: ) He says, "counting," for as ye are one in substance, and in the honor which cometh of God, it follows that the matter is one of estimation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:135
verses.text: Now in the case of those who are greater and lesser, he would not have said "counting," but honor them that are better than yourselves, as he says in another place, "Obey them that have the rule over you, and submit to them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:136
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:137
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:138
verses.text: ) In that instance subjection is the result of the nature of the case, in this of our own judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:139
verses.text: "In lowliness of mind," he says, "each counting other better than themselves," as Christ also did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:140
verses.text: Thus are their explanations overthrown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:141
verses.text: It remains that I speak of our own after I have first spoken of theirs summarily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:142
verses.text: When exhorting to lowliness of mind, Paul would never have brought forward a lesser one, as obedient to a greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:143
verses.text: If he were exhorting servants to obey their masters, he might have done so with propriety, but when exhorting the free to obey the free, to what purpose could he bring forward the subjection of a servant to a master? of a lesser to a greater? He says not, "Let the lesser be subject to the greater," but ye who are of equal honor with each other be ye subject, "each counting other better than themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:144
verses.text: Why then did he not bring forward even the obedience of the wife, and say, As the wife obeys her husband, so do ye also obey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:145
verses.text: Now if he did not bring forward that state in which there is equality and liberty, since in that the subjection is but slight, how much less would he have brought forward the subjection of a slave? I said above, that no one so praises a man for abstaining from evil, nor even mentions him at all; no one who desires to praise a man for continence would say, he has not committed adultery, but, he has abstained from his own wife; for we do not consider abstinence from evil as a matter of praise at all, it would be ridiculous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:146
verses.text: I said that the "form of a servant" was a true form, and nothing less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:147
verses.text: Therefore "the form of God" also is perfect, and no less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:148
verses.text: Why says he not, "being made in the form of God," but "being in the form of God"? This is the same as the saying, "I am that I am".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:149
verses.text: (Ex.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:150
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:151
verses.text: ) "Form" implies unchangeableness, so far as it is form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:152
verses.text: It is not possible that things of one substance should have the form of another, as no man has the form of an angel, neither has a beast the form of a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:153
verses.text: How then should the Son?  Now in our own case, since we men are of a compound nature, form pertains to the body, but in the case of a simple and altogether uncompounded nature it is of the substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:154
verses.text: But if thou contendest that he speaks not of the Father, because the word is used without the article, in many places this is meant, though the word be used without the article.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:155
verses.text: Why say I, in many places? for in this very place he says, "He counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God," using the word without the article, though speaking of God the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:156
verses.text: I would add our own explanation, but I fear that I shall overwhelm your minds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:157
verses.text: Meanwhile remember what has been said for their refutation; meanwhile let us root out the thorns, and then we will scatter the good seed after that the thorns have been rooted out, and a little rest has been given to the land; that when rid of all the evil thence contracted, it may receive the divine seed with full virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:158
verses.text: Let us give thanks to God for what has been spoken; let us entreat Him to grant us the guarding and safe keeping thereof, that both we and ye may rejoice, and the heretics may be put to shame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:159
verses.text: Let us beseech Him to open our mouth for what follows, that we may with the same earnestness lay down our own views.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:160
verses.text: Let us supplicate Him to vouchsafe us a life worthy of the faith, that we may live to His glory, and that His name may not be blasphemed through us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:161
verses.text: For, "woe unto you," it is written, "through whom the name of God is blasphemed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:162
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:163
verses.text: lii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:164
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:165
verses.text: nearly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:166
verses.text: ) For if, when we have a son, (and what is there more our own than a son,) if therefore when we have a son, and are blasphemed through him, we publicly renounce him, turn away from him, and will not receive him; how much more will God, when He has ungrateful servants who blaspheme and insult Him, turn away from them and hate them? And who will take up him whom God hates and turns away from, but the Devil and the demons? And whomsoever the demons take, what hope of salvation is left for him? what consolation in life?  As long as we are in the hand of God, "no one is able to pluck us out" (John x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:167
verses.text: ), for that hand is strong; but when we fall away from that hand and that help, then are we lost, then are we exposed, ready to be snatched away, as a "bowing wall, and a tottering fence" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:168
verses.text: lxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:169
verses.text: ); when the wall is weak, it will be easy for all to surmount.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:170
verses.text: Think not this which I am about to say refers to Jerusalem alone, but to all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:171
verses.text: And what was spoken of Jerusalem? "Now will I sing to my well-beloved a song of my beloved touching His vineyard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:172
verses.text: My well-beloved hath a vineyard in a very fruitful hill, and I made a fence about it, and surrounded it with a dike, and planted it with the vine of Sorech, and built a tower in the midst of it, and also dug a wine press in it, and I looked that it should bring forth grapes, and it brought forth thorns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:173
verses.text: And now, O men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, judge between Me and My vineyard.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:174
verses.text: What should have been done to My vineyard, that I have not done to it? Wherefore, when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, brought it forth thorns? Now therefore I will tell you what I will do to My vineyard: I will take away the hedge thereof, and it shall be for a prey, and I will break down the wall thereof, and it shall be trodden down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:175
verses.text: And I will leave My vineyard, and it shall not be pruned or digged, but thorns shall come up upon it, as upon a desert land.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:176
verses.text: I will also command the clouds, that they rain no rain upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:177
verses.text: For the vineyard of the Lord of Sabaoth is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah His pleasant plant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:178
verses.text: I looked that it should do judgment, but it did iniquity, and a cry instead of righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:179
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:180
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:181
verses.text: –, LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:182
verses.text: ) This is spoken also of every soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:183
verses.text: For when God who loveth man hath done all that is needful and man then bringeth forth thorns instead of grapes, He will take away the fence, and break down the wall, and we shall be for a prey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:184
verses.text: For hear what another prophet speaks in his lamentations: "Why hast thou broken down her fences, so that all they which pass by the way do pluck her? The boar out of the wood doth ravage it, and the wild beasts of the field feed on it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:185
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:186
verses.text: lxxx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:188
verses.text: ) In the former place He speaks of the Mede and the Babylonian, here nought is said of them, but "the boar," and "the solitary beast" is the Devil and all his host, because of the ferocity and impurity of his disposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:189
verses.text: For when it would show us his rapacity, it saith, "As a roaring lion he walketh about, seeking whom he may devour" ( Pet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:190
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:191
verses.text: ): when his poisonous, his deadly, his destructive nature, it calleth him a snake, and a scorpion; "For tread," saith He, "upon serpents and scorpions, and upon all the power of the enemy" (Luke x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:192
verses.text: ): when it would represent his strength as well as his venom, it calleth him a dragon; as when it says, This dragon "whom thou hast formed to take his pastime therein".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:193
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:194
verses.text: civ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:195
verses.text: ) Scripture everywhere calleth him a dragon, and a crooked serpent, and an adder (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:196
verses.text: lxxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:198
verses.text: ); he is a beast of many folds, and varied in his devices, and his strength is great, he moves all things, he disturbs all things, he turns all things up and down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:199
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:200
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:201
verses.text: ; li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:202
verses.text: ; Ezek.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:203
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:204
verses.text: ; xxxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:205
verses.text: ) But fear not, neither be afraid; watch only, and he will be as a sparrow; "for," saith He, "tread upon serpents and scorpions".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:206
verses.text: If we will, He causes him to be trodden down under our feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:207
verses.text: See now what scorn is it, yea, what misery, to see him standing over our heads, who has been given to us to tread down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:208
verses.text: And whence is this? it is of ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:209
verses.text: If we choose, he becomes great; and if we choose, he becomes of small power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:210
verses.text: If we take heed to ourselves, and take up our stand with Him who is our King, he draws himself in, and will be no better than a little child in his warfare against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:211
verses.text: Whensoever we stand apart from Him, he puffeth himself up greatly, he uttereth terrible sounds, he grindeth his teeth, because he finds us without our greatest help.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:212
verses.text: For he will not approach to us, except God permit him; for if he dared not to enter into the herd of swine, except by God's permission, how much less into men's souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:213
verses.text: But God does permit him, either chastening or punishing us, or making us more approved, as in the case of Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:214
verses.text: Seest thou that he came not to him, neither dared to be near him, but trembled and quaked? Why speak I of Job? When he leaped upon Judas, he dared not to seize on him wholly, and to enter into him, until Christ had severed him from the sacred band.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:215
verses.text: He attacked him indeed from without, but he dared not enter in, but when he saw him cut off from that holy flock, he leaped upon him with more than wolfish vehemence, and left him not till he had slain him with a double death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:216
verses.text: These things are written for our admonition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:217
verses.text: What gain have we from knowing that one of the twelve was a traitor? what profit? what advantage? Much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:218
verses.text: For, when we know whence it was that he arrived at this deadly counsel, we are on our guard that we too suffer not the like.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:219
verses.text: Whence came he to this? From the love of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:220
verses.text: He was a thief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:221
verses.text: For thirty pieces of silver he betrayed his Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:222
verses.text: So drunken was he with the passion, he betrayed the Lord of the world for thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:223
verses.text: What can be worse than this madness? Him to whom nothing is equivalent, nothing is equal, "before whom the nations are as nothing" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:224
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:225
verses.text: ), Him did he betray for thirty pieces of silver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:226
verses.text: A grievous tyrant indeed is the love of gold, and terrible in putting the soul beside itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:227
verses.text: A man is not so beside himself through drunkenness as through love of money, not so much from madness and insanity as from love of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:228
verses.text: For tell me, why didst thou betray Him? He called thee, when a man unmarked and unknown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:229
verses.text: He made thee one of the twelve, He gave thee a share in His teaching, He promised thee ten thousand good things, He caused thee to work wonders, thou wert sharer of the same table, the same journeys, the same company, the same intercourse, as the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:230
verses.text: And were not these things sufficient to restrain thee? For what reason didst thou betray Him? What hadst thou to charge Him with, O wicked one? Rather, what good didst thou not receive at His hands? He knew thy mind, and ceased not to do His part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:231
verses.text: He often said, "One of you shall betray Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:232
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:233
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:234
verses.text: ) He often marked thee, and yet spared thee, and though He knew thee to be such an one, yet cast thee not out of the band.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:235
verses.text: He still bore with thee, He still honored thee, and loved thee, as a true disciple, and as one of the twelve, and last of all (oh, for thy vileness!), He took a towel, and with His own unsullied hands He washed thy polluted feet, and even this did not keep thee back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:236
verses.text: Thou didst steal the things of the poor, and that thou mightest not go on to greater sin, He bore this too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:237
verses.text: Nothing persuaded thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:238
verses.text: Hadst thou been a beast, or a stone, wouldest thou not have been changed by these kindnesses towards thee, by these wonders, by these teachings? Though thou wast thus brutalized, yet still He called thee, and by wondrous works He drew thee, thou wast more senseless than a stone, to Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:239
verses.text: Yet for none of these things didst thou become better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:240
verses.text: Ye wonder perhaps at such folly of the traitor; dread therefore that which wounded him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:241
verses.text: He became such from avarice, from the love of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:242
verses.text: Cut out this passion, for to these diseases does it give birth; it makes us impious, and causes us to be ignorant of God, though we have received ten thousand benefits at His hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:243
verses.text: Cut it out, I entreat you, it is no common disease, it knoweth how to give birth to a thousand destructive deaths.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:244
verses.text: We have seen his tragedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:245
verses.text: Let us fear lest we too fall into the same snares.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:246
verses.text: For this is it written, that we too should not suffer the same things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:247
verses.text: Hence did all the Evangelists relate it, that they might restrain us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:248
verses.text: Flee then far from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:249
verses.text: Covetousness consisteth not alone in the love of much money, but in loving money at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:250
verses.text: It is grievous avarice to desire more than we need.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:251
verses.text: Was it talents of gold that persuaded the traitor? For thirty pieces of silver he betrayed his Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:252
verses.text: Do ye not remember what I said before, that covetousness is not shown in receiving much, but rather in receiving little things? See how great a crime he committed for a little gold, rather not for gold, but for pieces of silver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:253
verses.text: It cannot, it cannot be that an avaricious man should ever see the face of Christ! This is one of the things which are impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:254
verses.text: It is a root of evils, and if he that possesses one evil thing, falls from that glory, where shall he stand who bears with him the root? He who is the servant of money cannot be a true servant of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:255
verses.text: Christ Himself hath declared that the thing is impossible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:256
verses.text: "Ye cannot," He says, "serve God and Mammon," and, "No man can serve two masters" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:257
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:258
verses.text: ), for they lay upon us contrary orders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:259
verses.text: Christ says, "Spare the poor"; Mammon says, "Even from the naked strip off the things they have".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:260
verses.text: Christ says, "Empty thyself of what thou hast"; Mammon says, "Take also what thou hast not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:261
verses.text: Seest thou the opposition, seest thou the strife? How is it that a man cannot easily obey both, but must despise one? Nay, does it need proof? How so? Do we not see in very deed, that Christ is despised, and Mammon honored? Perceive ye not how that the very words are painful? How much more then the thing itself? But it does not appear so painful in reality, because we are possessed with the disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:262
verses.text: Now if the soul be but a little cleansed of the disease, as long as it remains here, it can judge right; but when it departs elsewhere, and is seized by the fever, and is engaged in the pleasure of the thing, it hath not its perception clear, it hath not its tribunal uncorrupt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:263
verses.text: Christ says, "Whosoever he be of you that renounceth not all that he hath, he cannot be My disciple" (Luke xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:264
verses.text: ); Mammon says, "Take the bread from the hungry".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:265
verses.text: Christ says, "Cover the naked" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:266
verses.text: lviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:267
verses.text: ); the other says, "Strip the naked".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:268
verses.text: Christ says, "Thou shalt not hide thyself from thine own flesh," (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:269
verses.text: lviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:270
verses.text: ) and those of thine own house; Mammon says, "Thou shalt not pity those of thine own seed; though thou seest thy mother or thy father in want, despise them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:271
verses.text: Why say I father or mother? "Even thine own soul," he says, "destroy it also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:272
verses.text: And he is obeyed! Alas! he who commands us cruel, and mad, and brutal things, is listened to rather than He who bids us gentle and healthful things! For this is hell appointed; for this, fire; for this, a river of fire; for this, a worm that dieth not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:273
verses.text: I know that many hear me say these things with pain, and indeed it is not without pain I say them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:274
verses.text: But why need I say these things? I could wish the things concerning the kingdom to be ever my discourse, of the rest, of the waters of rest, of the green pastures, as the Scripture says, "He maketh me to lie down in green pastures, He leadeth me beside the still waters" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:275
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:276
verses.text: ), there He maketh me to dwell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:277
verses.text: I could wish to speak of the place, whence "sorrow and sighing shall flee away".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:278
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:279
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:280
verses.text: )  I could wish to discourse of the pleasures of being with Christ, though they pass all expression and all understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:281
verses.text: Yet would I speak of these things according to my power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:282
verses.text: But what shall I do? it is not possible to speak concerning a kingdom to one that is diseased and in fever; then we must needs speak of health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:283
verses.text: It is not possible to speak of honor to one that is brought to trial, for at that time his desire is that he be freed from judgment, and penalty, and punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:284
verses.text: If this be not effected, how shall the other be? It is for this cause that I am continually speaking of these things, that we may the sooner pass over to those other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:285
verses.text: For this cause does God threaten hell, that none may fall into hell, that we all may obtain the kingdom; for this cause we too make mention continually of hell, that we may thrust you onward towards the kingdom, that when we have softened your minds by fear, we may bring you to act worthily of the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:286
verses.text: Be not then displeased at the heaviness of our words, for the heaviness of these words lightens our souls from sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:287
verses.text: Iron is heavy, and the hammer is heavy, but it forms vessels fit for use, both of gold and silver, and straightens things which are crooked; and if it were not heavy, it would have no power to straighten the distorted substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:288
verses.text: Thus too our heavy speech has power to bring the soul into its proper tone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:289
verses.text: Let us not then flee from heaviness of speech, nor the strokes it gives; the stroke is not given that it may break in pieces or tear the soul, but to straighten it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:290
verses.text: We know how we strike, how by the grace of God we inflict the stroke, so as not to crush the vessel, but to polish it, to render it straight, and meet for the Master's use, to offer it glittering in soundness, skillfully wrought against that Day of the river of fire, to offer it having no need of that burning pile.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:291
verses.text: For if we expose not ourselves to fire here, we must needs be burned there, it cannot be otherwise; "For the day of the Lord is revealed by fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:292
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:293
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:294
verses.text: ) Better is it that ye be burned for a little space by our words, than for ever in that flame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:295
verses.text: That this will indeed be so, is plain, and I have ofttimes given you reasons which cannot be gainsaid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:296
verses.text: We ought truly to be persuaded from the Scriptures, but forasmuch as some are contentious, we have also brought forward many arguments from reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:297
verses.text: Nothing hinders that I now mention them, and what were they? God is just.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:298
verses.text: We all acknowledge this, both Greeks and Jews, and Heretics, and Christians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:299
verses.text: But many sinners have had their departure without punishment, many righteous men have had their departure after suffering ten thousand grievous things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 7:300
verses.text: If then God be just, where will He reward their good to the one, and their punishment to the other, if there be no hell, if there be no resurrection? This reason then do ye constantly repeat to them and to yourselves, and it will not suffer you to disbelieve the resurrection, and whoso disbelieves not the resurrection will take care to live with all heed so as to obtain eternal happiness, of which may we all be counted worthy, by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:2
verses.text: Philippians ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:3
verses.text: –  "Have this mind in you which was also in Christ Jesus: who, being in the form of God, counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God; but emptied Himself, taking upon Him the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men: and being found in fashion as a man, He humbled Himself, becoming obedient unto death, yea, the death of the cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:4
verses.text: Wherefore also God highly exalted Him, and gave Him the Name which is above every name: that in the Name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things on earth, and things under the earth; and that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:5
verses.text: I have stated the views of the heretics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:6
verses.text: It is befitting that I now speak of what is our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:7
verses.text: They say that the words, "He counted it not a prize," are of wrongfully seizing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:8
verses.text: We have proved, that this is altogether vapid and impertinent, for no man would exhort another to humility on such grounds, nor in this sort does he praise God, or even man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:9
verses.text: What is it then, beloved? Give heed to what I now say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:10
verses.text: Since many men think, that, when they are lowly, they are deprived of their proper right, and debased, Paul, to take away this fear, and to show that we must not be affected thus, says that God, the only begotten, who was in the form of God, who was no whit inferior to the Father, who was equal to Him, "counted it not a prize to be on an equality with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:11
verses.text: Now learn what this meaneth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:12
verses.text: Whatsoever a man robs, and takes contrary to his right, he dares not lay aside, from fear lest it perish, and fall from his possession, but he keeps hold of it continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:13
verses.text: He who possesses some dignity which is natural to him, fears not to descend from that dignity, being assured that nothing of this sort will happen to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:14
verses.text: As for example, Absalom usurped the government, and dared not afterwards to lay it aside.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:15
verses.text: We will go to another example, but if example cannot present the whole matter to you, take it not amiss, for this is the nature of examples, they leave the greater part for the imagination to reason out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:16
verses.text: A man rebels against his sovereign, and usurps the kingdom: he dares not lay aside and hide the matter, for if he once hide it, straightway it is gone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:17
verses.text: Let us also take another example; if a man takes anything violently, he keeps firm hold of it continually, for if he lay it down, he straightway loses it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:18
verses.text: And generally speaking, they who have aught by rapine are afraid to lay it by, or hide it, or not to keep constantly in that state which they have assumed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:19
verses.text: Not so they, who have possessions not procured by rapine, as Man, who possesses the dignity of being a reasonable being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:20
verses.text: But here examples fail me, for there is no natural preëminence amongst us, for no good thing is naturally our own; but they are inherent in the nature of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:21
verses.text: What does one say then? That the Son of God feared not to descend from His right, for He thought not Deity a prize seized.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:22
verses.text: He was not afraid that any would strip Him of that nature or that right, Wherefore He laid it aside, being confident that He should take it up again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:23
verses.text: He hid it, knowing that He was not made inferior by so doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:24
verses.text: For this cause, Paul says not, "He seized not," but, "He counted it not a prize"; He possessed not that estate by seizure, but it was natural, not conferred, it was enduring and safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:25
verses.text: Wherefore he refused not to take the form of an inferior.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:26
verses.text: The tyrant fears to lay aside the purple robe in war, while the king does it with much safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:27
verses.text: Why so? because he holds his power not as a matter of seizure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:28
verses.text: He did not refuse to lay it aside, as one who had usurped it, but since He had it as His own by nature, since it could never be parted from Him, He hid it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:29
verses.text: This equality with God He had not by seizure, but as his own by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:30
verses.text: Wherefore "He emptied Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:31
verses.text: Where be they who affirm, that He underwent constraint, that He was subjected? Scripture says, "He emptied Himself, He humbled Himself, and became obedient unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:32
verses.text: How did He empty Himself? By taking "the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men, and being found in fashion as a man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:33
verses.text: It is written, "He emptied Himself" in reference to the text, "each counting other better than himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:34
verses.text: Since had He been subjected, had He not chosen it of His own accord, and of His own free will, it would not have been an act of humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:35
verses.text: For if He knew not that so it must be, He would have been imperfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:36
verses.text: If, not knowing it, He had waited for the time of action, then would He not have known the season.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:37
verses.text: But if He both knew that so it must be, and when it must be, wherefore should He submit to be subjected? To show, they say, the superiority of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:38
verses.text: But this shows not the superiority of the Father, but His own inferiority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:39
verses.text: For is not the name of the Father sufficient to show the priority of the Father? For apart from Him, the son has all the same things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:40
verses.text: For this honor is not capable of passing from the Father to the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:41
verses.text: What then say the heretics? See, say they, He did not become man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:42
verses.text: The Marcionites, I mean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:43
verses.text: But why? He was "made in the likeness of man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:44
verses.text: But how can one be "made in the likeness of men"? by putting on a shadow? But this is a phantom, and no longer the likeness of a man, for the likeness of a man is another man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:45
verses.text: And what wilt thou answer to John, when he says, "The Word became flesh"? (John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:46
verses.text: ) But this same blessed one himself also says in another place, "in the likeness of sinful flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:47
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:48
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:49
verses.text: )  "And being found in fashion as a man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:50
verses.text: See, they say, both "in fashion," and "as a man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:51
verses.text: To be as a man, and to be a man in fashion, is not to be a man indeed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:52
verses.text: To be a man in fashion is not to be a man by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:53
verses.text: See with what ingenuousness I lay down what our enemies say, for that is a brilliant victory, and amply gained, when we do not conceal what seem to be their strong points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:54
verses.text: For this is deceit rather than victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:55
verses.text: What then do they say? let me repeat their argument.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:56
verses.text: To be a man in fashion is not to be a man by nature; and to be as a man, and in the fashion of a man, this is not to be a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:57
verses.text: So then to take the form of a servant, is not to take the form of a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:58
verses.text: Here then is an inconsistency; and wherefore do you not first of all solve this difficulty? For as you think that this contradicts us, so do we say that the other contradicts you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:59
verses.text: He says not, "as the form of a servant," nor "in the likeness of the form of a servant," nor "in the fashion of the form of a servant," but "He took the form of a servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:60
verses.text: What then is this? for there is a contradiction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:61
verses.text: There is no contradiction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:62
verses.text: God forbid! it is a cold and ridiculous argument of theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:63
verses.text: He took, say they, the form of a servant, when He girded Himself with a towel, and washed the feet of His disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:64
verses.text: Is this the form of a servant? Nay, this is not the form, but the work of a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:65
verses.text: It is one thing that there should be the work of a servant, and another to take the form of a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:66
verses.text: Why did he not say, He did the work of a servant, which were clearer? But nowhere in Scripture is "form" put for "work," for the difference is great: the one is the result of nature, the other of action.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:67
verses.text: In common speaking, too, we never use "form" for "work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:68
verses.text: Besides, according to them, He did not even take the work of a servant, nor even gird Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:69
verses.text: For if all was a mere shadow, there was no reality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:70
verses.text: If He had not real hands, how did He wash their feet? If He had not real loins, how did He gird Himself with a towel? and what kind of garments did he take? for Scripture says, "He took His garments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:71
verses.text: (John xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:72
verses.text: ) So then not even the work is found to have really taken place, but it was all a deception, nor did He even wash the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:73
verses.text: For if that incorporeal nature did not appear, it was not in a body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:74
verses.text: Who then washed the disciples' feet?  Again, what in opposition to Paul of Samosata? for what did he affirm? The very same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:75
verses.text: But it is no emptying of Himself, that one who is of human nature, and a mere man, should wash his fellow-servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:76
verses.text: For what we said against the Arians, we must repeat against these too, for they differ not from one another, save by a little space of time; both the one and the other affirm the Son of God to be a creature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:77
verses.text: What then shall we say to them? If He being a man washed man, He emptied not, He humbled not Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:78
verses.text: If He being a man seized not on being equal with God, He is not deserving of praise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:79
verses.text: That God should become man, is great, unspeakable, inexpressible humility; but what humility is there in that one, who was a man should do the works of men? And where is the work of God ever called "the form of God"? for if he were a mere man, and was called the form of God by reason of His works, why do we not do the same of Peter, for he wrought greater deeds than Christ Himself? Why say you not of Paul, that he had the form of God? Why did not Paul give an example of himself, for he wrought a thousand servile works, and did not even refuse to say, "For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:80
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:81
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:82
verses.text: )  These are absurdities and trifles! Scripture says, He "emptied Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:83
verses.text: How did He empty Himself? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:84
verses.text: What was His emptying? what His humiliation? was it because He wrought wonders? This both Paul and Peter did, so that this was not peculiar to the Son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:85
verses.text: What then means, "Being made in the likeness of men"? He had many things belonging to us, and many He had not; for instance, He was not born of wedlock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:86
verses.text: He did no sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:87
verses.text: These things had He which no man has.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:88
verses.text: He was not what he seemed only, but He was God also; He seemed to be a man, but He was not like the mass of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:89
verses.text: For He was like them in flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:90
verses.text: He means then, that He was not a mere man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:91
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "in the likeness of men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:92
verses.text: For we indeed are soul and body, but He was God, and soul and body, wherefore he says, "in the likeness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:93
verses.text: For lest when you hear that He emptied Himself, you should think that some change, and degeneracy, and loss is here; he says, whilst He remained what He was, He took that which He was not, and being made flesh He remained God, in that He was the Word.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:94
verses.text: (John i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:95
verses.text: )  In this then He was like man, and for this cause Paul says, "and in fashion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:96
verses.text: Not that His nature degenerated, nor that any confusion arose, but He became man in fashion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:97
verses.text: For when He had said that "He took the form of a servant," he made bold to say this also, seeing that the first would silence all objectors; since when he says, "In the likeness of sinful flesh," he says not that He had not flesh, but that that flesh sinned not, but was like to sinful flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:98
verses.text: Like in what? in nature, not in sin, therefore was His like a sinful soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:99
verses.text: As then in the former case the term similarity was used, because He was not equal in everything, so here also there is similarity, because He is not equal in everything, as His not being born of wedlock, His being without sin, His being not a mere man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:100
verses.text: And he well said "as a man," for He was not one of the many, but "as" one of the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:101
verses.text: The Word who was God did not degenerate into man, nor was His substance changed, but he appeared as a man; not to delude us with a phantom, but to instruct us in humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:102
verses.text: When therefore he says, "as a man," this is what He means; since he calls Him a man elsewhere also, when he says, "there is one God, one Mediator also between God and men, Himself man, Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:103
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:104
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:105
verses.text: )  Thus much against these heretics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:106
verses.text: I must now speak against such as deny that He took a soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:107
verses.text: If "the form of God" is "perfect God," then the "form of a servant" is "a perfect servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:108
verses.text: Again, against the Arians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:109
verses.text: Here concerning His divinity, we no longer find "He became," "He took," but "He emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men"; here concerning his humanity we find "He took, He became".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:110
