verses.text: He became the latter, He took the latter; He was the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:111
verses.text: Let us not then confound nor divide the natures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:112
verses.text: There is one God, there is one Christ, the Son of God; when I say "One," I mean a union, not a confusion; the one Nature did not degenerate into the other, but was united with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:113
verses.text: "He humbled Himself, becoming obedient unto death, yea, the death of the cross".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:114
verses.text: See, says one, He voluntarily became obedient; he was not equal to Him whom He obeyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:115
verses.text: O ye obstinate ones and unwise! This doth not at all lower Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:116
verses.text: For we too become obedient to our friends, yet this has no effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:117
verses.text: He became obedient as a Son to His Father; He fell not thus into a servile state, but by this very act above all others guarded his wondrous Sonship, by thus greatly honoring the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:118
verses.text: He honored the Father, not that thou shouldest dishonor Him, but that thou shouldest the rather admire Him, and learn from this act, that He is a true Son, in honoring His Father more than all besides.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:119
verses.text: No one hath thus honored God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:120
verses.text: As was His height, such was the correspondent humiliation which He underwent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:121
verses.text: As He is greater than all, and no one is equal to Him, so in honoring His Father, He surpassed all, not by necessity, nor unwillingly, but this too is part of His excellence; yea, words fail me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:122
verses.text: Truly it is a great and unspeakable thing, that He became a servant; that He underwent death, is far greater; but there is something still greater, and more strange; why? All deaths are not alike; His death seemed to be the most ignominious of all, to be full of shame, to be accursed; for it is written, "Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:123
verses.text: (Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:124
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:125
verses.text: ; Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:126
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:127
verses.text: ) For this cause the Jews also eagerly desired to slay Him in this manner, to make Him a reproach, that if no one fell away from Him by reason of His death, yet they might from the manner of His death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:128
verses.text: For this cause two robbers were crucified with Him, and He in the midst, that He might share their ill repute, and that the Scripture might be fulfilled, "And he was numbered with the transgressors".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:129
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:130
verses.text: liii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:131
verses.text: ) Yet so much the more doth truth shine forth, so much the more doth it become bright; for when His enemies plot such things against His glory, and it yet shines forth, so much the greater does the matter seem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:132
verses.text: Not by slaying Him, but by slaying Him in such sort did they think to make Him abominable, to prove Him more abominable than all men, but they availed nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:133
verses.text: And both the robbers also were such impious ones, (for it was afterward that the one repented,) that, even when on the cross, they reviled Him; neither the consciousness of their own sins, nor their present punishment, nor their suffering the same things themselves, restrained their madness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:134
verses.text: Wherefore the one spake to the other, and silenced him by saying, "Dost thou not even fear God, seeing thou art in the same condemnation?" (Luke xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:135
verses.text: ) So great was their wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:136
verses.text: Wherefore it is written, "God also highly exalted Him, and gave Him the Name which is above every name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:137
verses.text: When the blessed Paul hath made mention of the flesh, he fearlessly speaks of all His humiliation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:138
verses.text: For until he had mentioned that He took the form of a servant, and while he was speaking of His Divinity, behold how loftily he doth it, (loftily, I say, according to his power; for he speaks not according to His own worthiness, seeing that he is not able).

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:139
verses.text: "Being in the form of God, He counted it not a prize to be equal with God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:140
verses.text: But when he had said, that He became Man, henceforth he fearlessly discourseth of His low estate, being confident that the mention of His low estate would not harm His Divinity, since His flesh admitted this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:141
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:143
verses.text: "Wherefore also God highly exalted Him, and gave Him the Name which is above every name: that in the Name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; and that every tongue should confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:144
verses.text: Let us say against the heretics, If this is spoken of one who was not incarnate, if of God the Word, how did He highly exalt Him? Was it as if He gave Him something more than He had before? He would then have been imperfect in this point, and would have been made perfect for our sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:145
verses.text: For if He had not done good deeds to us, He would not have obtained that honor! "And gave Him the Name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:146
verses.text: See, He had not even a name, as you say! But how, if He received it as His due, is He found here to have received it by grace, and as a gift? And that "the Name which is above every name": and of what kind, let us see, is the Name? "That at the Name of Jesus," saith He, "every knee should bow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:147
verses.text: They (the heretics) explain name by glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:148
verses.text: This glory then is above all glory, and this glory is in short that all worship Him! But ye hold yourselves far off from the greatness of God, who think that ye know God, as He knoweth Himself, and from this it is plain, how far off ye are from right thoughts of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:149
verses.text: And this is plain from hence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:150
verses.text: Is this, tell me, glory? Therefore before men were created, before the angels or the archangels, He was not in glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:151
verses.text: If this be the glory which is above every glory, (for this is the name that is "above every name,") though He were in glory before, yet was He in glory inferior to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:152
verses.text: It was for this then that He made the things that are, that He might be raised to glory, not from His own goodness, but because He required glory from us! See ye not their folly? see ye not their impiety?  Now if they had said this of Him that was incarnate, there had been reason, for God the Word allows that this be said of His flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:153
verses.text: It touches not His divine nature, but has to do altogether with the dispensation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:154
verses.text: What means "of things in heaven, and things in the earth, and things under the earth"? It means the whole world, and angels, and men, and demons; or that both the just and the living and sinners,  "And every tongue," should "confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:155
verses.text: That is, that all should say so; and this is glory to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:156
verses.text: Seest thou how wherever the Son is glorified, the Father is also glorified? Thus too when the Son is dishonored, the Father is dishonored also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:157
verses.text: If this be so with us, where the difference is great between fathers and sons, much more in respect of God, where there is no difference, doth honor and insult pass on to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:158
verses.text: If the world be subjected to the Son, this is glory to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:159
verses.text: And so when we say that He is perfect, wanting nothing, and not inferior to the Father, this is glory to the Father, that he begat such a one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:160
verses.text: This is a great proof of His power also, and goodness, and wisdom, that He begat one no whit inferior, neither in wisdom nor in goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:161
verses.text: When I say that He is wise as the Father, and no whit inferior, this is a proof of the great wisdom of the Father; when I say that He is powerful as the Father, this is a proof of the Father's power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:162
verses.text: When I say that He is good as the Father, this is the greatest evidence of His goodness, that He begat such (a Son), in no whit less or inferior to Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:163
verses.text: When I say that He begat Him not inferior in substance but equal, and not of another substance, in this I again wonder at God, His power, and goodness, and wisdom, that He hath manifested to us another, of Himself, such as Himself, except in His not being the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:164
verses.text: Thus whatsoever great things I say of the Son, pass on to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:165
verses.text: Now if this small and light matter (for it is but a light thing to God's glory that the world should worship Him) is to the glory of God, how much more so are all those other things?  Let us then believe to His glory, let us live to His glory, for one is no use without the other; when we glorify Him rightly, but live not rightly, then do we especially insult Him, because we are enrolled under Him as a Master and Teacher, and yet despise Him, and stand in no dread of that fearful judgment seat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:166
verses.text: It is no wonder that the heathen live impurely; this merits not such condemnation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:167
verses.text: But that Christians, who partake in such great mysteries, who enjoy so great glory, that they should live thus impurely, this is worst of all, and unbearable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:168
verses.text: For tell me; He was obedient to the uttermost, wherefore He received the honor which is on high.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:169
verses.text: He became a servant, wherefore He is Lord of all, both of Angels, and of all other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:170
verses.text: Let us too not suppose then that we descend from what is our due, when we humble ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:171
verses.text: For thus may we be more highly exalted; and with reason; then do we especially become admirable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:172
verses.text: For that the lofty man is really low, and that the lowly man is exalted, the sentence of Christ sufficiently declares.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:173
verses.text: Let us however examine the matter itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:174
verses.text: What is it to be humbled? Is it not to be blamed, to be accused, and calumniated? What is it to be exalted? It is to be honored, to be praised, to be glorified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:175
verses.text: Well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:176
verses.text: Let us see how the matter is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:177
verses.text: Satan was an angel, he exalted himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:178
verses.text: What then? was he not humbled beyond all other? has he not the earth as his place? is he not condemned and accused by all? Paul was a man, and humbled himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:179
verses.text: What then? is he not admired? is he not praised? is he not lauded? is he not the friend of Christ? Wrought he not greater things than Christ? did he not ofttimes command the devil as a captive slave? did he not carry him about as an executioner? did he not hold him up to scorn? held he not his head bruised under his feet? did he not with much boldness beg of God that others too might do the same? Why am I saying? Absalom exalted himself, David humbled himself; which of the twain was raised up, which became glorious? For what could be a more evident proof of humility than these words which that blessed Prophet spoke of Shimei, "Let him curse, for the Lord hath bidden him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:180
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:181
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:182
verses.text: ) And if you please, we will examine the very cases themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:183
verses.text: The Publican humbled himself, although the case can hardly be called humility; but how? He answered in a right-minded manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:184
verses.text: The Pharisee exalted himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:185
verses.text: What then? let us also examine the matters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:186
verses.text: Let there be two men, both rich, and highly honored, and elevated by wisdom and power, and other worldly advantages; then let one of them seek honor from all, let him be angry if he receive it not, let him require more than is due and exalt himself; let the other despise the whole matter, bear himself unkindly towards no one on this account, and evade honor when offered to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:187
verses.text: For it is not possible to obtain glory any other way than by fleeing from glory, for as long as we pursue it, it flies from us, but when we flee from it, then it pursues us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:188
verses.text: If thou wouldest be glorious, do not desire glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:189
verses.text: If thou wouldest be lofty, do not make thyself lofty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:190
verses.text: And further, all honor him who does not grasp at honor, but spurn him who seeks it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:191
verses.text: For the human race somehow or other is fond of contention, and leans to contrary feeling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:192
verses.text: Let us therefore despise glory, for thus we shall be enabled to become lowly, or rather to become exalted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:193
verses.text: Exalt not thyself, that thou mayest be exalted by another; he that is exalted by himself is not exalted by others, he who is humbled by himself is not humbled by others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:194
verses.text: Haughtiness is a great evil, it is better to be a fool than haughty; for in the one case, the folly is only a perversion of intellect, but in the other case it is still worse, and is folly joined with madness: the fool is an evil to himself; but the haughty man is a plague to others too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:195
verses.text: This misery comes of senselessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:196
verses.text: One cannot be haughty-minded without being a fool; and he that is brimfull of folly is haughty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:197
verses.text: Listen to the Wise Man, who says, "I saw a man wise in his own conceit; there is more hope of a fool than of him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:198
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:199
verses.text: xxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:200
verses.text: ) Seest thou how it was not without reason I said that the evil of which I am speaking is worse than that of folly, for it is written, "There is more hope of a fool than of him"? Wherefore, Paul too said, "Be not wise in your own conceits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:201
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:202
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:203
verses.text: ) Tell me what description of bodies do we say are in good health, those which are much inflated, and are inwardly full of much air and water, or those which are kept low, and have their surface such as marks restraint? It is manifest that we should choose the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:204
verses.text: So, too with the soul, that which is puffed up has a worse disease than dropsy, whilst that which is under restraint is freed from all evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:205
verses.text: How great then are the good things which lowliness of mind bringeth to us! What wouldest thou have? Forbearance? freedom from anger? love to our fellow-men? soberness? attentiveness? All these good things spring from lowly-mindedness, and their contraries from haughtiness: the haughty man must needs be also insolent, a brawler, wrathful, bitter, sullen, a beast rather than a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:206
verses.text: Art thou strong, and proud thereat? Thou shouldest rather be humble on this account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:207
verses.text: Why art thou proud for a thing of nought? For even a lion is bolder than thou, a wild boar is stronger, and thou art not even as a fly in comparison with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:208
verses.text: Robbers too, and violaters of tombs, and gladiators, and even thine own slaves, and those perchance who are more stupid still, are stronger than thou.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:209
verses.text: Is this then a fit subject for praise? Art thou proud of such a matter? Bury thyself for shame!  But art thou handsome and beautiful? This is the boast of crows! Thou art not fairer than the peacock, as regards either its color or its plumage; the bird beats thee in plumage, it far surpasseth thee in its feathers and in its color.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:210
verses.text: The swan too is passing fair, and many other birds, with whom if thou art compared thou wilt see that thou art nought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:211
verses.text: Often too worthless boys, and unmarried girls, and harlots, and effeminate men have had this boast; is this then a cause for haughtiness? But art thou rich? Whence so? what hast thou? Gold, silver, precious stones! This is the boast of robbers also, of man-slayers, of those who work in the mines.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:212
verses.text: That which is the labor of criminals becomes to thee a boast! But dost thou adorn and deck thyself out? Well, we may see horses also decked out, and among the Persians camels too, and as for men, all those who are about the stage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:213
verses.text: Art thou not ashamed to boast thyself of these things, if unreasoning animals, and slaves, and man-slayers, and effeminate, and robbers, and violaters of tombs, share with thee? Dost thou build splendid palaces? and what of this? Many jackdaws dwell in more splendid houses, and have more noble retreats.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:214
verses.text: Dost thou not see how many, who were mad after money, have built houses in fields and desert places, that are retreats for jackdaws? But art thou proud on account of thy voice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:215
verses.text: Thou canst by no means sing with clearer and sweeter tones than the swan or the nightingale.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:216
verses.text: Is it for thy varied knowledge of arts? But what is wiser than the bee in this; what embroiderer, what painter, what geometrician, can imitate her works? Is it for the fineness of thy apparel? But here the spiders beat thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:217
verses.text: Is it for the swiftness of thy feet? Again the first prize is with unreasoning animals, the hare, and the gazelle, and all the beasts which are not wanting in swiftness of foot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:218
verses.text: Hast thou traveled much? Not more than the birds; their transit is more easily made, they have no need of provisions for the way, nor beasts of burden, for their wings are all-sufficient for them; this is their vessel, this their beast of burden, this their car, this is even their wind, in short, all that a man can name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:219
verses.text: But art thou clear sighted? Not as the gazelle; not as the eagle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:220
verses.text: Art thou quick of hearing? the ass is more so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:221
verses.text: Of scent? the hound suffers thee not to surpass him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:222
verses.text: Art thou a good provider? yet thou art inferior to the ant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:223
verses.text: Dost thou gather gold? Yet not as the Indian ants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:224
verses.text: Art thou proud because of thy health? Unreasoning creatures are far better than we both in habit of body, and in independence; they fear no poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:225
verses.text: "Behold the birds of the heaven, that they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:226
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:227
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:228
verses.text: ) "And surely," He means, "God has not created the irrational animals superior to ourselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:229
verses.text: Dost thou mark what want of consideration is here? Dost thou observe the lack of all investigation? Dost thou observe the great advantage which we derive from an investigation of the points? He, whose mind is lifted up above all men, is found to be even lower than the irrational creatures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:230
verses.text: But we will have pity upon him, and not follow his example; nor because the limits of our mortal nature are too narrow for his conceit of himself, will we proceed to lower him to the level of the beasts that are without reason, but will lift him up from thence, not for his own sake, for he deserves no better fate, but that we may set forth the lovingkindness of God, and the honor which He has vouchsafed us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:231
verses.text: For there are things, yes, there are things wherein the irrational animals have no participation with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:232
verses.text: And of what sort are these? Piety, and a life based on virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:233
verses.text: Here thou canst never speak of fornicators, nor of effeminate persons, nor of murderers, for from them we have been severed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:234
verses.text: And what then is this which is found here? We know God, His Providence we acknowledge, and are embued with true philosophy concerning immortality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:235
verses.text: Here let the irrational animals give place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:236
verses.text: They cannot contend with us in these points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:237
verses.text: We live in self-command.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:238
verses.text: Here the irrational animals have nothing in common with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:239
verses.text: For, while coming behind all of them, we exercise dominion over them; for herein lies the superiority of our dominion, that, while coming behind them, we yet reign over them: that thou mightest be instructed that the cause of these things is, not thyself, but God who made thee, and gave thee reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:240
verses.text: We set nets and toils for them, we drive them in, and they are at our mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:241
verses.text: Self-command, a compliant temper, mildness, contempt of money, are prerogatives of our race; but since thou who art one of those blinded by presumption hast none of these, thou doest well in entertaining notions either above the level of mankind, or beneath the very irrational creatures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:242
verses.text: For this is the nature of folly and of audacity; it is either unduly elevated, or on the other hand it is equally depressed, never observing a proper proportion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:243
verses.text: We are equal to angels in this respect, that we have a Kingdom pledged to us, the choir, unto which Christ is joined.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:244
verses.text: He that is a man may be scourged, yet does he not succumb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:245
verses.text: A man laughs at death, is a stranger to fear and trembling, he does not covet more than he has.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:246
verses.text: So that they all who are not like this are beneath the irrational animals.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:247
verses.text: For when in the things of the body thou wouldest have the advantage, but hast no advantage in the things that concern the soul, how art thou aught else than inferior to the irrational animals? For bring forward one of the vicious and unthinking, of those that are living in excess and to self.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:248
verses.text: The horse surpasses him in warlike spirit, the boar in strength, the hare in swiftness, the peacock in grace, the swan in fineness of voice, the elephant in size, the eagle in keenness of sight, all birds in wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:249
verses.text: Whence then dost thou derive thy title to rule the irrational creatures? from reason? But thou hast it not? For whosoever ceases to make a due use of it, is again inferior to them; for when though possessing reason he is more irrational than they, it had been better if he had never from the first become capable of exercising reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:250
verses.text: For it is not the same thing after having received dominion to betray the trust, as to let pass the season to receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:251
verses.text: That sovereign, who is below the level of his guards, had better never have had on the purple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:252
verses.text: And it is the very self-same thing in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 8:253
verses.text: Knowing then that without virtue we are inferior to the very irrational animals, let us exercise ourselves therein, that we may become men, yea rather angels, and that we may enjoy the promised blessings, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:2
verses.text: Philippians ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:3
verses.text: –  "So then, my beloved, even as ye have always obeyed, not as in my presence only, but now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling; for it is God which worketh in you both to will and to work for His good pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:4
verses.text: Do all things without murmurings and disputings: that ye may be blameless and harmless, children of God without blemish in the midst of a crooked and perverse generation, among whom ye are seen as lights in the world, holding forth the word of life; that I may have whereof to glory in the day of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:5
verses.text: The admonitions which we give ought to be accompanied with commendations; for thus they become even welcome, when we refer those whom we admonish to that measure of zeal which they have themselves exhibited; as Paul, for instance, did here; and observe with what singular discretion; "So then, my beloved," he says; he did not say simply "be obedient," not until he had first commended them in these words, "even as ye have always obeyed"; i-e: "it is not other men, but your own selves, whom I bid you take example by".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:6
verses.text: "Not as in my presence only, but much more in my absence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:7
verses.text: And why, "much more in my absence"? "Ye seemed perhaps at that time to be doing everything out of respect to me, and from a principle of shame, but that is no longer so; if then ye make it evident that ye now strive more earnestly, it is also made evident that neither then was it done out of consideration to me, but for God's sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:8
verses.text: Tell me, what wouldest thou? "not that ye give heed to me, but that ye 'work out your own salvation with fear and trembling'"; for it is impossible for one, who lives devoid of fear, to set forth any high or commanding example; and he said not merely "with fear," but "and with trembling," which is an excessive degree of fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:9
verses.text: Such fear had Paul: and therefore he said, I fear "lest having preached to others, I myself should be rejected".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:10
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:11
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:12
verses.text: ) For if without the aid of fear temporal things can never be achieved, how much less spiritual matters; for I desire to know, who ever learnt his letters without fear? who has become a proficient in any art, without fear? But if, when the devil does not lie in the way, where indolence is the only obstacle, so much of fear is necessary merely in order that we may master that indolence which is natural to us; where there is so fierce a war, so great hindrances, how can we by any possibility be saved without fear?  And how may this fear be produced? If we but consider that God is everywhere present, heareth all things, seeth all things, not only whatsoever is done and said, but also all that is in the heart, and in the depth of the soul, for He is "quick to discern the thoughts and intents of the heart" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:13
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:14
verses.text: ), if we so dispose ourselves, we shall not do or say or imagine aught that is evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:15
verses.text: Tell me, if thou hadst to stand constantly near the person of a ruler, wouldest not thou stand there with fear? and how standing in God's presence, dost thou laugh and throw thyself back, and not conceive fear and dread? Let it never be that thou despisest His patient endurance, for it is to bring thee to repentance that He is longsuffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:16
verses.text: Whenever thou eatest, consider that God is present, for He is present; whenever thou art preparing to sleep, or giving way to passion, if thou art robbing another, or indulging in luxury, or whatever thou art about, thou wilt never fall into laughter, never be inflamed with rage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:17
verses.text: If this be thy thought continually, thou wilt continually be in "fear and trembling," forasmuch as thou art standing beside the King.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:18
verses.text: The architect, though he be experienced, though he be perfectly master of his art, yet stands with "fear and trembling," lest he fall down from the building.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:19
verses.text: Thou too hast believed, thou hast performed many good deeds, thou hast mounted high: secure thyself, be in fear as thou standest, and keep a wary eye, lest thou fall thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:20
verses.text: For manifold are the spiritual sorts of wickedness which aim to cast thee down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:21
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:22
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:23
verses.text: ) "Serve the Lord with fear," he says, "and rejoice unto Him with trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:24
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:25
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:26
verses.text: ) And how is rejoicing compatible with "trembling"? Yet this, be assured, is the only rejoicing; for when we perform some good work, and such as beseemeth those who do anything "with trembling," then only do we rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:27
verses.text: "Work out your own salvation with fear and trembling": he says not "work," but "work out," i-e: with much earnestness, with much diligence; but as he had said, "with fear and trembling," see how he relieves their anxiety: for what does he say? "It is God that worketh in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:28
verses.text: Fear not because I said, "with fear and trembling".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:29
verses.text: I said it not with this view, that thou shouldest give up in despair, that thou shouldest suppose virtue to be somewhat difficult to be attained, but that thou mightest be led to follow after it, and not spend thyself in vain pursuits; if this be the case, God will work all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:30
verses.text: Do thou be bold; "for it is God that worketh in you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:31
verses.text: If then He worketh, it is our part to bring a mind ever resolute, clenched and unrelaxed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:32
verses.text: "For it is God that worketh in you both to will and to work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:33
verses.text: "If He does Himself work in us to will, how dost thou exhort us? for if He works Himself even the will, the words, which you speak to us, have no meaning, 'that ye have obeyed'; for we have not 'obeyed'; it is without meaning that thou sayest, 'with fear and trembling'; for the whole is of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:34
verses.text: It was not for this that I said to you, "for it is He that worketh in you both to will and to work," but my object was to relieve your anxiety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:35
verses.text: If thou wilt, in that case He will "work in thee to will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:36
verses.text: Be not affrighted, thou art not worsted; both the hearty desire and the accomplishment are a gift from Him: for where we have the will, thenceforward He will increase our will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:37
verses.text: For instance, I desire to do some good work: He has wrought the good work itself, and by means of it He has wrought also the will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:38
verses.text: Or he says this in the excess of his piety, as when he declares that our well-doings are gifts of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:39
verses.text: As then, when he calls these gifts, he does not put us out of the pale of free will, but accords to us free will, so when he says, "to work in us to will," he does not deprive us of free will, but he shows that by actually doing right we greatly increase our heartiness in willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:40
verses.text: For as doing comes of doing, so of not doing comes not doing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:41
verses.text: Hast thou given an alms? thou art the more incited to give.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:42
verses.text: Hast thou refused to give? thou art become so much the more disinclined.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:43
verses.text: Hast thou practiced temperance for one day? Thou hast an incitement for the next likewise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:44
verses.text: Hast thou indulged to excess? Thou hast increased the inclination to self-indulgence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:45
verses.text: "When a wicked man cometh into the depth of vice, then he despises".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:46
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:47
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:48
verses.text: ) As, then, when a man cometh into the depth of iniquity, he turns a despiser; so when he cometh into the depth of goodness, he quickens his exertions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:49
verses.text: For as the one runs riot in despair, so the second, under a sense of the multitude of good things, exerts himself the more, fearing lest he should lose the whole.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:50
verses.text: "For His good pleasure," he says, that is, "for love's sake," for the sake of pleasing Him; to the end that what is acceptable to Him may take place; that things may take place according to His will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:51
verses.text: Here he shows, and makes it a ground of confidence, that He is sure to work in us, for it is His will that we live as He desires we should, and if He desires it, He Himself both worketh in us to this end, and will certainly accomplish it; for it is His will that we live aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:52
verses.text: Seest thou, how he does not deprive us of free will?  "Do all things without murmurings and disputings".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:53
verses.text: The devil, when he finds that he has no power to withdraw us from doing right, wishes to spoil our reward by other means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:54
verses.text: For he has taken occasion to insinuate pride or vainglory, or if none of these things, then murmuring, or, if not this, misgivings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:55
verses.text: Now then see how Paul sweeps away all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:56
verses.text: He said on the subject of humility all that he did say, to overthrow pride; he spoke of vainglory, that is, "not as in my presence only"; he here speaks of "murmuring and disputing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:57
verses.text: But why, I want to know, when in the case of the Corinthians he was engaged in uprooting this evil tendency, did he remind them of the Israelites, but here has said nothing of the sort, but simply charged them? Because in that case the mischief was already done, for which reason there was need of a more severe stroke and a sharper rebuke; but here he is giving admonitions to prevent its being done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:58
verses.text: Severe measures then were not called for in order to secure those that had not yet been guilty; as in leading them to humility he did not subjoin the instance in the Gospel, wherein the proud were punished, but laid the charge as from God's lips (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:59
verses.text: ? xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:61
verses.text: ); and he addresses them as free, as children of pure birth, not as servants; for in the practice of virtue a rightminded and generous person is influenced by those who do well, but one of bad principles by those who do not do well; the one by the consideration of honor, the other of punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:62
verses.text: Wherefore also writing to the Hebrews, he said, bringing forward the example of Esau, "Who for one mess of meat sold his own birthright" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:63
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:64
verses.text: ); and again, "if he shrink back, my soul hath no pleasure in him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:65
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:66
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:67
verses.text: ) And among the Corinthians were many who had been guilty of fornication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:68
verses.text: Therefore he said, "Lest when I come again my God should humble me before you, and I should mourn for many that have sinned heretofore, and repented not of the uncleanness, and fornication, and lasciviousness which they committed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:69
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:70
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:71
verses.text: ) That ye may be blameless," says he, "and harmless"; i-e: irreproachable, unsullied; for murmuring occasions no slight stain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:72
verses.text: And what means "without disputing"? Is it good, or not good? Do not dispute, he says, though it be trouble, or labor, or any thing else whatever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:73
verses.text: He did not say, "that ye be not punished," for punishment is reserved for the thing; and this he made evident in the Epistle to the Corinthians; but here he said nothing of the sort; but he says, "That ye may be blameless and harmless, children of God without blemish, in the midst of a crooked and perverse generation, among whom ye are seen as lights in the world, holding forth the word of life, that I may have whereof to glory in the day of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:74
verses.text: Observest thou that he is instructing these not to murmur? So that murmuring is left for unprincipled and graceless slaves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:75
verses.text: For tell me, what manner of son is that, who murmurs at the very time that he is employed in the affairs of his father, and is working for his own benefit? Consider, he says, that you are laboring for yourself, that it is for yourself that you are laying up; it is for those to murmur, when others profit by their labors, others reap the fruit, while they bear the burden; but he that is gathering for himself, why should he murmur? Because his wealth does not increase? But it is not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:76
verses.text: Why does he murmur who acts of free-will, and not by constraint? It is better to do nothing than to do it with murmuring, for even the very thing itself is spoilt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:77
verses.text: And do you not remark that in our own families we are continually saying this; "it were better for these things never to be done, than to have them done with murmuring"? and we had often rather be deprived of the services some one owes us, than submit to the inconvenience of his murmuring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:78
verses.text: For murmuring is intolerable, most intolerable; it borders upon blasphemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:79
verses.text: Otherwise why had those men to pay a penalty so severe? It is a proof of ingratitude; the murmurer is ungrateful to God, but whoso is ungrateful to God does thereby become a blasphemer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:80
verses.text: Now there were at that time, if ever, uninterrupted troubles, and dangers without cessation: there was no pause, no remission: innumerable were the horrors, which pressed upon them from all quarters; but now we have profound peace, a perfect calm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:81
verses.text: Wherefore then murmur? Because thou art poor? Yet think of Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:82
verses.text: Or because sickness is thy lot? What then if, with the consciousness of as many excellencies and as high attainments as that holy man, thou hadst been so afflicted? Again reflect on him, how that for a long time he never ceased to breed worms, sitting upon a dunghill and scraping his sores; for the account says that "(after a long time had passed,) then said his wife unto him, How long wilt thou persist, saying, Yet a little while I bide in expectation? Speak some word against the Lord, and die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:83
verses.text: (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:84
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:85
verses.text: ) But your child is dead? What then if thou hadst lost all thy children, and that by an evil fate, as he did? For ye know, ye know well, that it is no slight alleviation to take our place beside the sick man, to close the mouth, to shut the eyes, to stroke the beard, to hear the last accents; but that just man was vouchsafed none of these consolations, they all being overwhelmed at once.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:86
verses.text: And what do I say? Hadst thou, thine own self, been bidden to slay and offer up thine own son, and to see the body consumed, like that blessed Patriarch, what then wouldst thou have felt whilst erecting the altar, laying on the wood, binding the child? But there are some who revile thee? What then would be thy feelings did thy friends, come to administer consolation to thee, speak like Job's? For, as it is, innumerable are our sins, and we deserve to be reproached; but in that case he who was true, just, godly, who kept himself from every evil deed, heard the contrary of those laid to his charge by his friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:87
verses.text: What then, tell me, if thou hadst heard thy wife exclaiming in accents of reproach; "I am a vagabond and a servant, wandering from place to place, and from house to house, waiting until the sun goes down, that I may rest from the woes that encompass me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:88
verses.text: (Job ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:89
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:90
verses.text: ) Why dost thou speak so, O foolish woman? for is thine husband to blame for these things? Nay, but the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:91
verses.text: "Speak a word against God," she says, "and die";—and if thereupon the stricken man had cursed and died, how wouldest thou be the better?—No disease you can name is worse than that of his, though you name ten thousand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:92
verses.text: It was so grievous, that he could no longer be in the house and under cover; such, that all men gave him up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:93
verses.text: For if he had not been irrecoverably gone, he would never have taken his seat without the city, a more pitiable object than those afflicted with leprosy; for these are both admitted into houses, and they do herd together; but he passing the night in the open air, was naked upon a dunghill, and could not even bear a garment upon his body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:94
verses.text: How so? Perhaps there would only have been an addition to his pangs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:95
verses.text: For "I melt the clods of the earth," he says, "while I scrape off my sore".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:96
verses.text: (Job vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:97
verses.text: , LXX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:98
verses.text: ) His flesh bred sores and worms in him, and that continually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:99
verses.text: Seest thou how each one of us sickens at the hearing of these things? but if they are intolerable to hear, is the sight of them more tolerable? and if the sight of them is intolerable, how much more intolerable to undergo them? And yet that righteous man did undergo them, not for two or three days, but for a long while, and he did not sin, not even with his lips.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:100
verses.text: What disease can you describe to me like this, so exquisitely painful? for was not this worse than blindness? "I look on my food," he says, "as a fetid mass".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:101
verses.text: (Job vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:102
verses.text: ) And not only this, but that which affords cessation to others, night and sleep, brought no alleviation to him, nay, were worse than any torture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:103
verses.text: Hear his words: "Why dost thou scare me with dreams, and terrify me through visions? If it be morning, I say, When will it be evening?" (Job vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:105
verses.text: ), and he murmured not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:106
verses.text: And there was not only this; but reputation in the eyes of the world was added; for they forthwith concluded him to be guilty of endless crimes, judging from all that he suffered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:107
verses.text: And accordingly this is the consideration, which his friends urged upon him; "Know therefore that God exacteth less of thee than thine iniquities deserve".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:108
verses.text: (Job xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:109
verses.text: ) Wherefore he himself said, "But now they that are younger than I have me in derision, whose fathers I disdained to set with the dogs of my flock".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:110
verses.text: (Job xxx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:111
verses.text: ) And was not this worse than many deaths? Yet though assaulted on all sides by a flood like this, when there raged around him a fearful storm, clouds, rain, lightnings, whirling winds, and waterspouts, he remained himself unmoved, seated as it were in the midst of this surge, thus awful and overwhelming, as in a perfect calm, and no murmur escaped him; and this before the gift of grace, before that aught was declared concerning a resurrection, before aught concerning hell and punishment and vengeance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:112
verses.text: Yet we, who hear both Prophets and Apostles and Evangelists speaking to us, and have innumerable examples set before us, and have been taught the tidings of a Resurrection, yet harbor discontent, though no man can say that such a fate as this has been his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:113
verses.text: For if one has lost money, yet not all that great number of sons and daughters, or if he has, perchance it was that he had sinned; but for him, he lost them suddenly, in the midst of his sacrifices, in the midst of the service which he was rendering to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:114
verses.text: And if any man has at one blow lost property to the same amount, which can never be, yet he has not had the further affliction of a sore all over his body, he has not scraped the humors that covered him; or if this likewise has been his fate, yet he has not had men to upbraid and reproach him, which is above all things calculated to wound the feelings, more than the calamities we suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:115
verses.text: For if when we have persons to cheer and console us in our misfortunes, and to hold out to us fair prospects, we yet despond, consider what it was to have men upbraiding him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:116
verses.text: If the words, "I looked for some to have pity, but there was no man, and for comforters, but I found none" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:117
verses.text: lxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:118
verses.text: ), describe intolerable misery, how great an aggravation to find revilers instead of comforters! "Miserable comforters are ye all" (Job xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:119
verses.text: ), he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:120
verses.text: If we did but revolve these subjects continually in our minds, if we well weighed them, no ills of this present time could ever have force to disturb our peace, when we turned our eyes to that athlete, that soul of adamant, that spirit impenetrable as brass.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:121
verses.text: For as though he had borne about him a body of brass or stone, he met all events with a noble and constant spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:122
verses.text: Taking these things to heart, let us do everything "without murmuring and disputing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:123
verses.text: Is it some good work that thou hast before thee, and dost thou murmur? wherefore? art thou then forced? for that there are many about you who force you to murmur, I know well, says he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:124
verses.text: This he intimated by saying, "in the midst of a crooked and perverse generation"; but it is this that deserves admiration, that we admit no such feeling when under galling provocation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:125
verses.text: For the stars too give light in the night, they shine in the dark, and receive no blemish to their own beauty, yea they even shine the brighter; but when light returns, they no longer shine so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:126
verses.text: Thus thou too dost appear with the greater lustre, whilst thou holdest straight in the midst of the crooked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:127
verses.text: This it is which deserves our admiration, the being "blameless"; for that they might not urge this plea, he himself set it down by anticipation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:128
verses.text: What means "holding fast the word of life"? i-e: "being destined to live, being of those that are gaining salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:129
verses.text: Observe how immediately he subjoins the rewards, which are in reserve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:130
verses.text: Lights i-e: luminaries, he says, retain the principle of light; so do ye the principle of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:131
verses.text: What means "the word of life"? Having the seed of life, i-e: having pledges of life, holding life itself, i-e: "having in yourselves the seed of life," this is what he calls "the word of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:132
verses.text: Consequently the rest are all dead, for by these words he signified as much; for otherwise those others likewise would have held "the word of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:133
verses.text: "That I may have whereof to glory," he says; what is this? I too participate in your good deeds, he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:134
verses.text: So great is your virtue, as not only to save yourselves, but to render me illustrious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:135
verses.text: Strange kind of "boasting," thou blessed Paul! Thou art scourged, driven about, reviled for our sakes: therefore he adds, "in the day of Christ, that I did not run," he says, "in vain, nor labored in vain," but I always have a right to glory, he means, that I did not run in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:136
verses.text: "Yea, and if I am offered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:137
verses.text: He said not, "and if I die even," nor did he when writing to Timothy, for there, too, he has made use of the same expression, "For I am already being offered".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:138
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:139
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:140
verses.text: ) He is both consoling them about his own death, and instructing them to bear gladly the death that is for Christ's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:141
verses.text: I am become, he says, as it were a libation and a sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:142
verses.text: O blessed soul! His bringing them to God he calls a sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:143
verses.text: It is much better to present a soul than to present oxen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:144
verses.text: "If, then, over and above this offering," he says, "I add myself, my death as a libation, I rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:145
verses.text: For this he implies, when he says, "Yea, and if I am offered upon the sacrifice and service, I joy and rejoice with you all; and in the same manner do ye also joy and rejoice with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:146
verses.text: Why dost thou rejoice with them? Seest thou that he shows that it is their duty to rejoice? On the one hand then, I rejoice in being made a libation; on the other, I rejoice with you, in having presented a sacrifice; "and in the same manner do ye also joy and rejoice with me," that I am offered up; "rejoice with me," "who rejoice in myself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:147
verses.text: So that the death of the just is no subject for tears, but for joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:148
verses.text: If they rejoice, we should rejoice with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:149
verses.text: For it is misplaced for us to weep, while they rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:150
verses.text: "But," it is urged, "we long for our wonted intercourse".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:151
verses.text: This is a mere pretext and excuse; and that it is so, mark what he enjoins: "Rejoice with me, and joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:152
verses.text: Dost thou miss thy wonted intercourse? If thou wert thyself destined to remain here, there would be reason in what thou sayest; but if after a brief space thou wilt overtake him who has departed, what is that intercourse which thou dost seek? for it is only when he is forever severed from him that a man misses the society of another, but if he will go the same way that thou wilt go, what is the intercourse which thou longest for? Why do we not bewail all that are upon foreign travel? Do we not just a little, and cease after the first or the second day? If thou longest for thy wonted intercourse with him, weep so far only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:153
verses.text: "It is no evil that I suffer," says he, "but I even rejoice in going to Christ, and do ye not rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:154
verses.text: "Rejoice with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:155
verses.text: Let us too rejoice when we see a righteous man dying, and yet more even when any of the desperately wicked; for the first is going to receive the reward of his labors, but the other has abated somewhat from the score of his sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:156
verses.text: But it is said, perhaps he might have altered, had he lived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:157
verses.text: Yet God would never have taken him away, if there had been really a prospect of an alteration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:158
verses.text: For why should not He who orders all events for our salvation, allow him the opportunity, who gave promise of pleasing Him? If He leaves those, who never alter, much more those that do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:159
verses.text: Let then the sharpness of our sorrow be everywhere cut away, let the voice of lamentation cease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 9:160
verses.text: Let us thank God under all events: let us do all things without murmuring; let us be cheerful, and let us become pleasing to Him in all things, that we may also attain the good things to come, by the grace and loving-kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:1
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:2
verses.text: Philippians ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:3
verses.text: –  "But I hope in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy shortly unto you, that I also may be of good comfort, when I know your state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:4
verses.text: For I have no man likeminded, who will care truly for your state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:5
verses.text: For they all seek their own, not the things of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:6
verses.text: He had said, "have fallen out unto the progress of the Gospel; so that my bonds became manifest in Christ throughout the whole praetorian guard".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:7
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:8
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:10
verses.text: ) Again, "Yea, and if I am offered upon the sacrifice and service of your faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:11
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:12
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:13
verses.text: ) By these words he strengthened them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:14
verses.text: Perchance they might suspect that his former words were spoken just to comfort them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:15
verses.text: What then? "I send Timothy unto you," says he; for they desired to hear all things that concerned him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:16
verses.text: And wherefore said he not, "that ye may know my state," but, "that I may know yours"? Because Epaphroditus would have reported his state before the arrival of Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:17
verses.text: Wherefore further on he says, "But I counted it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:18
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:19
verses.text: ); but I wish to learn of your affairs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:20
verses.text: For it is likely that he had remained long time with Paul through his bodily weakness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:21
verses.text: So that he says, I wish to "know your state".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:22
verses.text: See then how he refers everything to Christ, even the mission of Timothy, saying, "I hope in the Lord Jesus," that is, I am confident that God will facilitate this for me, that I too may be of good courage, when I know your state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:23
verses.text: As I refreshed you when ye heard the very things of me which ye had prayed for, that the Gospel had advanced, that its enemies were put to shame, that the means by which they thought to injure, rather made me rejoice; thus too do I wish to learn of your affairs, that I too may be of good courage when I know your state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:24
verses.text: Here he shows that they ought to rejoice for his bonds, and to be conformed to them, for they begat in him great pleasure; for the words, "that I too may be of good comfort," imply, just as you are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:25
verses.text: Oh, what longing had he toward Macedonia! He testifies the same to the Thessalonians, as when he says, "But we, brethren, being bereaved of you for a short season," &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:26
verses.text: ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:27
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:28
verses.text: ) And here he says, "I hope to send Timothy" that I may "know your state," which is a proof of excessive care: for when he could not himself be with them, he sent his disciples, as he could not endure to remain, even for a little time, in ignorance of their state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:29
verses.text: For he did not learn all things by revelation of the Spirit, and for this we can see some reason; for if the disciples had believed that it were so, they would have lost all sense of shame, but now from expectation of concealment, they were more easily corrected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:30
verses.text: In a high degree did he call their attention by saying, "that I too may be of good comfort," and rendered them more zealous, so that, when Timothy came he might not find any other state of things, and report it to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:31
verses.text: He seems to have acted in like sort in his own person, when he delayed his coming to the Corinthians, that they might repent; wherefore he wrote, "to spare you I forbare to come to Corinth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:32
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:33
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:34
verses.text: ) For his love was manifested not simply in reporting his own state, but in his desire to learn of theirs; for this is the part of a soul which has a care of others, which takes thought for them, which is always wrestling for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:35
verses.text: At the same time too, he honors them by sending Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:36
verses.text: "What sayest thou? dost thou send Timothy? and wherefore?" Because "I have no one likeminded"; that is, none of those whose care is like mine, none who "will care truly for you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:37
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:38
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:39
verses.text: ) Had he then no one of those who were with him? No one likeminded, that is, who has yearnings and takes thought for you as I do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:40
verses.text: No one would lightly choose, he means, to make so long a journey for this purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:41
verses.text: Timothy is the one with me who loves you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:42
verses.text: For I might have sent others, but there was none like him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:43
verses.text: This then is that likemindedness, to love the disciples as the master loves them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:44
verses.text: "Who," says he, "will truly care for you," that is, as a father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:45
verses.text: "For they all seek their own, not the things of Jesus Christ" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:46
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:47
verses.text: ), their own comfort, their own safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:48
verses.text: This too he writes to Timothy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:49
verses.text: But why doth he lament such things as these? To teach us his hearers not to fall in like sort, to teach his hearers not to seek for remission from toil; for he who seeks remission from toil, seeks not the things that are Christ's, but his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:50
verses.text: We ought to be prepared against every toil, against every distress.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:51
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:52
verses.text: "Ye know the proof of him, that as a child serveth a father, so he served with me in furtherance of the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:53
verses.text: And that I speak not at random, "ye yourselves," he says, "know, that as a child serveth a father, so he served with me in furtherance of the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:54
verses.text: He presents then Timothy to them, and with reason, that he might enjoy much honor from them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:55
verses.text: This too he does when he writes to the Corinthians, and he says, "Let no man therefore despise him, for he worketh the work of the Lord as I also do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:56
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:57
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:58
verses.text: ) This he said not as caring for him, but for those who receive him, that they might receive a great reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:59
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:60
verses.text: "Him therefore," he says, "I hope to send forthwith, so soon as I shall see how it will go with me," that is, when I see where I stand, and what end my affairs will have.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:61
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:62
verses.text: "But I trust in the Lord that I also myself shall come to you shortly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:63
verses.text: I am not therefore sending him, as though I myself would not come, but that I may be of good courage when I know your state, that even in the mean time I may not be ignorant of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:64
verses.text: "But I trust in the Lord," says he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:65
verses.text: See how he makes all things depend on God, and speaks nothing of his own mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:66
verses.text: That is, God willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:67
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:68
verses.text: "But I counted it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother, and fellow-worker, and fellow-soldier".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:69
verses.text: And him too he sends with the same praises as Timothy, for he commended him on these two points; first, in that he loved them, when he says, "who will care truly for you"; and secondly, in that he had approved himself in the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:70
verses.text: And for the same reason, and in the same terms, he praises this man also: and how? By calling him a brother, and a fellow-worker, and not stopping at this point, but also "fellow-soldier," he showed how he shared in his dangers, and testifies of him the same things which he testifies of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:71
verses.text: For "fellow-soldier" is more than "fellow-worker"; for perchance he gave aid in quiet matters, yet not so in wars and dangers; but in saying "fellow-soldier," he showed this too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:72
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:73
verses.text: "To send to you your messenger, and minister to my needs"; that is, I give you your own, since I send to you him that is your own, or, perhaps, that is your Teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:74
verses.text: Again he adds many things concerning his love, in saying,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:76
verses.text: "Since he longed after you all, and was sore troubled, because ye had heard that he was sick.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:77
verses.text: For indeed he was sick nigh unto death: but God had mercy on him; and not on him only, but on me also, that I might not have sorrow upon sorrow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:78
verses.text: Here he aims at a farther point, making it manifest, that Epaphroditus too was well aware, how he was beloved of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:79
verses.text: And this is no light thing toward loving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:80
verses.text: You know how he was sick, he says; and he grieved that on his recovery he did not see you, and free you from the grief ye had by reason of his sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:81
verses.text: Here too he gives another reason for sending so late to them, not from any remissness, but he kept Timothy because he had no one else, (for, as he had written, he had "no one likeminded,") and Epaphroditus because of his sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:82
verses.text: He then shows that this was a long sickness, and had consumed much time, by adding, "for he was sick nigh unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:83
verses.text: You see how anxious Paul is to cut off from his disciples all occasion of slighting or contempt, and every suspicion that his not coming was because he despised them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:84
verses.text: For nothing will have such power to draw a disciple toward one, as the persuasion that his superior cares for him, and that he is full of heaviness on his account, for this is the part of exceeding love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:85
verses.text: Because "ye have heard," he says, "that he was sick; for he was sick nigh unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:86
verses.text: And that I am not making an excuse, hear what follows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:87
verses.text: "But God had mercy on him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:88
verses.text: What sayest thou, O heretic? Here it is written, that God's mercy retained and brought back again him who was on the point of departure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:89
verses.text: And yet if the world is evil, it is no mercy to leave a man in the evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:90
verses.text: Our answer to the heretic is easy, but what shall we say to the Christian? for he perchance will question, and say, "if to depart and to be with Christ is far better," how saith he that he hath obtained mercy? I would ask why the same Apostle says, that "it is more needful to abide with you"? For as it was needful for him, so too for this man, who would hereafter depart to God with more exceeding riches, and greater boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:91
verses.text: Hereafter that would take place, even if it did not now, but the winning souls is at an end for those who have once departed thither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:92
verses.text: In many places too, Paul speaks according to the common habits of his hearers, and not every where in accordance with his own heavenly wisdom: for he had to speak to men of the world who still feared death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:93
verses.text: Then he shows how he esteemed Epaphroditus, and thence he gets for him respect, by saying, that his preservation was so useful to himself, that the mercy which had been shown to Epaphroditus reached him also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:94
verses.text: Moreover, without this the present life is a good; were it not so, why does Paul rank with punishment untimely deaths? as when he says, "For this cause many are weak and sickly among you, and not a few sleep" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:95
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:96
verses.text: ); for the future life is not (merely) better than an evil state, since (then) it were not good, but better than a good state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:97
verses.text: "Lest I should have," he says, "sorrow upon sorrow"; sorrow from his death in addition to that which sprung from his sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:98
verses.text: By this he shows how much he prized Epaphroditus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:99
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:100
verses.text: "I have sent him therefore the more diligently".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:101
verses.text: What means "more diligently"? It is, without procrastination, without delay, with much speed, having bidden him lay all aside, and to go to you, that he might be freed from heaviness; for we rejoice not on hearing of the health of those we love, so much as when we see them, and chiefly so when this happens contrary to hope, as it was in the case of Epaphroditus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:102
verses.text: "I have sent him therefore the more diligently, that when ye see him again, ye may rejoice, and that I may be the less sorrowful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:103
verses.text: How "less sorrowful"? Because if ye rejoice, I too rejoice, and he too joys at a pleasure of such sort, and I shall be "less sorrowful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:104
verses.text: He said not sorrowless, but "less sorrowful," to show that his soul never was free from sorrow: for he who said, "Who is weak, and I am not weak? who is made to stumble, and I burn not?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:105
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:106
verses.text: ), when could such an one be free from sorrow? That is, this despondency I now cast off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:107
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:108
verses.text: "Receive him therefore in the Lord with all joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:109
verses.text: "In the Lord" either means spiritually and with much zeal, or rather "in the Lord" means God willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:110
verses.text: Receive him in a manner worthy of saints, as saints should be received with all joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:111
verses.text: All this he does for their sakes, not for that of his messengers, for greater gain has the doer than the receiver of a good deed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:112
verses.text: "And such hold in honor," that is, receive him in a manner worthy of saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:113
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:114
verses.text: "Because for the work of Christ he came nigh unto death, hazarding his life, to supply that which was lacking in your service towards me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:115
