verses.text: This man had been publicly sent by the city of the Philippians, who had come as minister to Paul, and perchance bringing him some contribution, for toward the end of the Epistle he shows that he also brought him money, when he says, "Having received of Epaphroditus the things that came from you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:116
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:117
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:118
verses.text: )  It is probable then, that on his arrival at the city of Rome, he found Paul in great and urgent peril, so that those who were accustomed to resort to him were unable safely to do so, but were themselves in peril by their very attendance; which is wont to happen chiefly in very great dangers, and the exceeding wrath of kings, (for when any one has offended the king, and is cast into prison, and is strictly guarded, then even his servants are debarred from access, which probably then befell Paul,) and that Epaphroditus, being of a noble nature, despised all danger, that he might go in unto him, and minister unto him, and do everything which need required.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:119
verses.text: He therefore sets forth two facts, by which he gains for him their respect; the one, that he was in jeopardy well nigh unto death, he says, for my sake; the other, that in so suffering he was representing their city, so that the recompense for that his peril would be accounted to those who sent him, as if the city had sent him as their ambassador, so that a kind reception of him and approval of what he had done may rather be called a participation in the things that he had dared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:120
verses.text: And he said not, "for my sake," but obtains the more credit for his words, by saying, "because for the work of God," since he acted not for my sake, but for God's sake "he was nigh unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:121
verses.text: What then? though by the providence of God he died not, yet he himself regarded not his life, and gave himself up to any suffering that might befall him, so as not to remit his attendance on me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:122
verses.text: And if he gave himself up to death to attend on Paul, much more would he have endured this for the Gospel's sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:123
verses.text: Or rather, this also had been for the Gospel's sake, even to have died for Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:124
verses.text: For we may bind about our brows the crown of martyrdom, not only by refusing to sacrifice, but such causes as these also make death martyrdom, and if I may say something startling, these latter do so far more than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:125
verses.text: For he who dares to face death for the lesser cause, will much rather for the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:126
verses.text: Let us therefore, when we see the Saints in danger, regard not our life, for it is impossible without daring ever to perform any noble act, but need is that he who takes thought beforehand for his safety here, should fall from that which is to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:127
verses.text: "To supply," he says, "your lack of service toward me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:128
verses.text: What is this? the city was not present, but by sending him, it fulfilled through him all service toward me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:129
verses.text: He therefore supplied your lack of service, so that for this reason too he deserves to enjoy much honor, since, what ye all should have done, this hath he performed on your behalf.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:130
verses.text: Here he shows that there is also a foregoing service rendered by those in safety to those in danger, for so he speaks of the lack, and the lack of service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:131
verses.text: Seest thou the spirit of the Apostle? These words spring not from arrogance, but from his great care towards them; for he calls the matter a "service" and a "lack," that they may not be puffed up, but be moderate, nor think that they have rendered some great thing, but rather be humble-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:132
verses.text: For we owe the saints a debt, and are not doing them a favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:133
verses.text: For as supplies are due by those who are in peace and not engaged in war to such as stand in the army and fight (for these stand on their behoof), thus too is it here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:134
verses.text: For if Paul had not taught, who would have cast him into prison? Wherefore we ought to minister to the Saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:135
verses.text: For is it not absurd to contribute to an earthly king, when engaged in war, all that he wants, as clothing and food, not according to his need alone, but abundantly, whilst to the King of Heaven, when engaged in war, and contending against far more bitter foes (for it is written, "our wrestling is not against flesh and blood") (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:136
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:137
verses.text: ), we will not supply urgent necessity? What folly is this! What ingratitude! What base love of gain! But, as it seems, the fear of man has greater force with us than hell, and the future torments.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:138
verses.text: For this cause, in truth, all things are turned upside down; for political affairs are daily accomplished with much earnestness, and one must not be left behind, whilst of spiritual things there is no account taken at all; but the things which are demanded of us of necessity, and with compulsion, as though we were slaves, and against our wills, are laid down by us with much readiness, while such as are asked from willing minds, and as if from free men, are again deficient.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:139
verses.text: I speak not against all, but against those who are behindhand with these supplies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:140
verses.text: For might not God have made these contributions compulsory? Yet He would not, for He has more care of you than of those whom you support.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:141
verses.text: Wherefore He would not that you should contribute of necessity, since there is no recompense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:142
verses.text: And yet many of those who stand here are lower minded than the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:143
verses.text: Consider how great things the Jews gave, tithes, first-fruits, tithes again, and again other tithes, and besides this thirteenths, and the shekel, and no one said, how much they devour; for the more they receive, the greater is the reward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:144
verses.text: They say not, They receive much, they are gluttons; which words I hear now from some.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:145
verses.text: They for their part, while they are building houses, and buying estates, still think they have nothing; but if any priest is clothed in dress more bright than usual, and enjoys more than what is necessary for his sustenance, or has an attendant, that he may not be forced himself to act unbecomingly, they set the matter down for riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:146
verses.text: And in truth we are rich even at this rate, and they admit it against their will; for we, though we have but little, are rich, whilst they, though they get everything about them, are poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:147
verses.text: How far shall our folly extend? does it not suffice to our punishment that we do no good deed, but must we add to it the punishment of evil speaking? For if what he has were your gifts, you lose your reward by upbraiding him for what you gave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:148
verses.text: In a word, if thou didst give it, why dost thou upbraid him? You have already borne witness to his poverty, by saying that what he has are your gifts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:149
verses.text: Why then dost thou upbraid? Thou shouldest not have given, didst thou intend so to do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:150
verses.text: But dost thou speak thus, when another gives? It is then more grievous, in that when thou thyself hast not given, thou upbraidest for another man's good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:151
verses.text: How great reward thinkest thou those who are thus spoken of will receive? It is for God's sake they thus suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:152
verses.text: How and wherefore? Had they so willed, they might have taken up a trader's life, even though they received it not from their ancestors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:153
verses.text: For I hear many speaking thus at random, when we say that a certain man is poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:154
verses.text: Had he willed, they say, he might have been rich, and then tauntingly add, His father, his grandfather, and I know not who was so; but now see what a robe he wears! But what? tell me, ought he to go about naked? You then start nice questionings on these points, but see lest thou thus speakest against thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:155
verses.text: Listen to that exhortation of Christ, which says, "Judge not that ye be not judged".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:156
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:157
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:158
verses.text: ) He might, it is true, if he had willed, have led a trader's or a merchant's life, and would surely not have lacked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:159
verses.text: But he would not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:160
verses.text: What then, says one, is he here profited? Tell me, what is he profited? Does he wear silken robes? Does he proudly clear his way through the forum with a troop of followers? Is he borne along on horseback? Does he build houses, having where to dwell? If he act so, I too accuse him, and spare him not, but declare that he is unworthy of the priesthood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:161
verses.text: For how can he exhort others not to spend their time on these superfluities, who cannot advise himself? But if he has sufficient for support, is he therefore doing wrong? Would you have him lead a vagabond life, and beg? Wouldest not thou too, his disciple, be put to shame? But if thy father in the flesh did this, thou wouldest think shame of the thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:162
verses.text: If thy spiritual father be compelled so to do, wilt thou not veil thy head, and even think thou art sinking into the earth? It is written, "A father's dishonor is a reproach to the children".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:163
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:164
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:165
verses.text: ) But what? Should he perish with famine? This were not like a pious man; for God willeth it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:166
verses.text: But what do they straightway philosophize? It is written, say they, "Get you no gold, nor silver, nor brass in your purses, neither two coats, nor yet staves" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:167
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:169
verses.text: ), whilst these men have three or four garments, and beds well spread.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:170
verses.text: I am forced now to heave a bitter sigh, and, but that it had been indecorous, I had wept too! How so? Because we are such curious searchers into the motes of others, while we feel not the beams in our own eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:171
verses.text: Tell me, why sayest thou not this to thyself? The answer is, Because the command is laid only on our Teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:172
verses.text: When then Paul says, "having food and covering we shall be therewith content" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:173
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:174
verses.text: ), says he this only to Teachers? By no means, but to all men; and this is clear, if we will begin farther back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:175
verses.text: For what does he say? "Godliness with contentment is great gain ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:176
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:177
verses.text: ); for we brought nothing into this world, it is certain that neither can we carry anything out" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:178
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:179
verses.text: ); he then straightway adds, "And having food and covering, we shall be therewith content; but they that desire to be rich, fall into a temptation and a snare, and many foolish and hurtful lusts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:180
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:181
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:183
verses.text: ) You see that this is spoken to all; and how is it when he says again, "Make not provision for the flesh to fulfill the lusts thereof" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:184
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:185
verses.text: ), is not this said absolutely to all? and what when he says, "Meats for the belly, and the belly for meats, but God shall bring to nought both it and them" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:186
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:187
verses.text: ); or what when he says, "But she that giveth herself to pleasure, is dead while she liveth" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:188
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:189
verses.text: ), speaking of a widow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:190
verses.text: Is then the widow a Teacher? Has not he said himself, "But I permit not a woman to teach, nor to have dominion over a man"? ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:191
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:192
verses.text: ) But if a widow, in old age, (and age has need of great attendance,) and a woman's nature too, (for the woman's sex, being weak, has need of more refreshment,) if then, where there is both the age and the nature, he suffers her not to live in luxury, but even says that she is dead, (for he did not simply forbid a life of luxury, but said, "she who giveth herself to luxury is dead while she liveth,") and thus hath cut her off, (for she that is dead is cut off,) what indulgence then will any man have, who does those things, for which a woman and an aged one too is punished?  Yet no one gives a thought to these things, no one searches them out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:193
verses.text: And this I have been compelled to say, not from any wish to free the priests from these charges, but to spare you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:194
verses.text: They indeed suffer no harm at your hands, even if it is with cause and justice that they are thus charged of being greedy of gain; for, whether ye speak, or whether ye forbear, they must there give an account to the Judge, so that your words hurt them not at all; but if your words are false besides, they for their part gain by these false accusations, whilst ye hurt yourselves by these means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:195
verses.text: But it is not so with you; for be the things true, which ye bring against them, or be they false, ye speak ill of them to your hurt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:196
verses.text: And how so? If they be true, in that ye judge your Teachers, and subvert order, ye do it to your hurt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:197
verses.text: For if we must not judge a brother, much less a Teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:198
verses.text: But if they be false, the punishment and retribution is intolerable; for of "every idle word ye shall give account".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:199
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:200
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:201
verses.text: ) For your sake then I thus act and labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:202
verses.text: But as I said, no one searches out these things, no one busies himself about these things, no one communes with himself on any of these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:203
verses.text: Would ye that I should add still more? "Whosoever forsaketh not all that he hath, saith the Christ, is not worthy of Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:204
verses.text: (Luke xiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:205
verses.text: ; Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:206
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:207
verses.text: ) What when he says, "It is hard for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of heaven"? (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:208
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:209
verses.text: ; Mark x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:210
verses.text: ) What when he says again, "Woe unto you that are rich, for ye have received your consolation"? (Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:211
verses.text: ) No one searches this out, no one bears it in mind, no one reasons with himself, but all sit as severe inquisitors on other men's cases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:212
verses.text: Yet this is to make themselves sharers in the charges.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:213
verses.text: But listen, that for your own sake I may free the priests from the charges, which ye say lie against them, for the persuasion that they transgress the law of God, inclines you not a little towards evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:214
verses.text: Come then, let us examine this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:215
verses.text: Christ said, "Provide neither gold nor silver, neither two coats, neither shoes, nor girdle, nor yet staves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:216
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:217
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:219
verses.text: ) What then? tell me, did Peter transgress this command? Surely he did so, in having a girdle and a garment, and shoes, for listen to the words of the Angel, "Gird thyself, and bind on thy sandals".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:220
verses.text: (Acts xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:221
verses.text: ) And yet he had no such great need of sandals, for at that season a man may go even unshod; their great use is in the winter, and yet he had them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:222
verses.text: What shall we say of Paul, when he writes thus to Timothy, "Do thy diligence to come before winter"? ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:223
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:224
verses.text: ) He gives him orders too and says, "The cloak that I left at Troas with Carpus bring when thou comest, and the books, especially the parchments".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:225
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:226
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:227
verses.text: ) See he speaks of a cloak, and no one can say that he had not another which he wore; for if he did not wear one at all, it were superfluous to order this one to be brought, and if he could not be without one to wear, it is clear he had a second.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:228
verses.text: What shall we say of his remaining "two whole years in his own hired dwelling"? (Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:229
verses.text: ) Did then this chosen vessel disobey Christ? this man who said, "Yet I live; and yet no longer I, but Christ liveth in me" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:230
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:231
verses.text: ), concerning whom Christ testified, saying, "He is a chosen vessel unto Me"? (Acts ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:232
verses.text: ) I ought to leave this difficulty with you, without supplying any solution to the question.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:233
verses.text: I ought to exact of you this penalty for your negligence in the Scriptures, for this is the origin of all such difficulties.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:234
verses.text: For we know not the Scriptures, we are not trained in the law of God, and so we become sharp inquirers into the faults of others, whilst we take no account of our own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:235
verses.text: I ought then to have exacted from you this penalty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:236
verses.text: But what shall I do? Fathers freely give to their sons many things beyond what is fitting: when their fatherly compassion is kindled, on seeing their child with downcast look, and wasted with grief, they themselves also feel sharper pangs than he, and rest not until they have removed the ground of his dejection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:237
verses.text: So be it at least here, be ye at least dejected at not receiving, that ye may receive well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:238
verses.text: What then is it? They opposed not, far be it; but diligently followed the commands of Christ, for those commands were but for a season, and not enduring; and this I say not from conjecture, but from the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:239
verses.text: And how? Luke relates that Christ said to His disciples, "When I sent you forth without purse, and wallet, and girdle, and shoes, lacked ye anything? And they said nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:240
verses.text: (Luke xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:241
verses.text: ) But for the future provide them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:242
verses.text: But tell me, what could he do? could he have but one coat? How then? If need was that this be washed, should he, because without it, stay at home? should he without it go abroad in an unbecoming manner, when need called? Consider what a thing it would have been that Paul, who made the circuit of the world with such great success, should remain at home for want of raiment, and thus hinder his noble work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:243
verses.text: And what if violent cold had set in, or rain had drenched it, or perhaps frozen in, how could he dry his raiment? must he again remain without it? And what if cold had deprived his body of strength? must he waste away with disease, and be unable to speak? For hear what he says to Timothy, to prove that they were not furnished with adamantine bodies, "Use a little wine for thy stomach's sake, and thine often infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:244
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:245
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:246
verses.text: ) And again, when he speaks of another, "I counted it necessary to send to you your messenger, and minister to my needs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:247
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:248
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:249
verses.text: ) "For indeed he was sick, nigh unto death; but God had mercy on him, and not on him only, but on me also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:250
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:251
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:252
verses.text: ) So that they were subject to every sort of sickness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:253
verses.text: What then? must they die? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:254
verses.text: For what cause then did Christ at that time give them that command? To show His own power, and to prove that in after times He was able to do it, though He did it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:255
verses.text: But wherefore did He not do it? They were much more admirable than the Israelites, whose shoes did not wax old, neither their garments, and that too whilst they were journeying through that desert where the glowing rays of the sun strike so hot, that they are capable of consuming even stones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:256
verses.text: (Ref.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:257
verses.text: to Deut.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:258
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:259
verses.text: ) Why then did he do this? For thy sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:260
verses.text: For since thou wouldest not remain in health, but be full of wounds, He gave you that which might serve for medicine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:261
verses.text: And this is hence manifest; could He not Himself have fed them? He that gave to thee, who wast an enemy with Him, would He not much more have given to Paul? He who gave to the Israelites, those murmurers, those fornicators, those idolaters, would He not much more have given to Peter, who spent all for His sake? He who suffered wicked men to possess aught, would He not much more have freely given to John, who for Him forsook even his father? Yet he would not: through your hands he feeds them, that you may be sanctified.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:262
verses.text: And see the excess of His lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:263
verses.text: He chose that His disciples should be in want, that thou mightest be a little refreshed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:264
verses.text: For if He had freed them from all want, they would have been much more admirable, far more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:265
verses.text: But then that which is to thee salvation would have been cut off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:266
verses.text: God willed not then that they should be admirable, that thou mightest be saved, but that they should rather be lowered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:267
verses.text: He hath suffered them to be less accounted of, that thou mightest be able to be saved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:268
verses.text: The Teacher who receiveth is not equally reverenced, but he who receives not is chiefly honored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:269
verses.text: But then in the latter case the disciple is not benefited, he is hindered of his fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:270
verses.text: Seest thou the wisdom of God who thus loveth man? For as He Himself sought not His own glory, nor had respect to Himself, but when He was in glory, chose to be dishonored for thy sake, thus too is it in the case of your Teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:271
verses.text: When they might have been highly reverenced, He preferred that they should be subject to contempt for thy sake, that thou mightest be able to profit, that thou mightest be able to be rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:272
verses.text: For he is in want of the things of this life, that you may abound in things spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:273
verses.text: If then He might have made them above all want, He showed that for thy sake He suffers them to be in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:274
verses.text: Knowing then these things, let us turn ourselves to well doing, not to accusations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:275
verses.text: Let us not be overcurious about the failings of others, but take account of our own; let us reckon up the excellences of other men, while we bear in mind our faults; and thus shall we be well pleasing to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:276
verses.text: For he who looks at the faults of others, and at his own excellences, is injured in two ways; by the latter he is carried up to arrogance, through the former he falls into listlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:277
verses.text: For when he perceives that such an one hath sinned, very easily will he sin himself; when he perceives that he hath in aught excelled, very easily becometh he arrogant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:278
verses.text: He who consigns to oblivion his own excellences, and looks at his failings only, whilst he is a curious enquirer of the excellences, not the sins, of others, is profited in many ways.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:279
verses.text: And how? When he sees that such an one hath done excellently, he is raised to emulate the same; when he sees that he himself hath sinned, he is rendered humble and modest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 10:280
verses.text: If we act thus, if we thus regulate ourselves, we shall be able to obtain the good things which are promised, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:1
verses.text: Homily X.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:2
verses.text: Philippians iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:3
verses.text: –  "Finally, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:4
verses.text: To write the same things to you, to me indeed is not irksome, but for you it is safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:5
verses.text: Beware of the dogs, beware of the evil workers, beware of the concision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:6
verses.text: For we are the circumcision, who worship God in the spirit, and glory in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:7
verses.text: Dejection and care, whenever they strain the soul beyond due measure, bereave it of its native force.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:8
verses.text: And therefore Paul relieves the Philippians, who were in great despondency, and they were in despondency because they did not know how matters were with Paul; they were in despondency because they thought that it was already over with him, because of the preaching, because of Epaphroditus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:9
verses.text: It is in giving them assurance on all these points that he introduces the words, "Finally, my brethren, rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:10
verses.text: "You no longer have," he says, "cause for despondency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:11
verses.text: You have Epaphroditus, for whose sake you were grieved; you have Timothy; I am myself coming to you; the Gospel is gaining ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:12
verses.text: What is henceforth wanting to you? Rejoice!"  Now he calls the Galatians indeed "children" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:13
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:14
verses.text: ), but these "brethren".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:15
verses.text: For when he aims either to correct anything or to show his fondness, he calls them "children"; but when he addresses them with greater honor, "brethren" is the title.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:16
verses.text: "Finally, my brethren," he says, "rejoice in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:17
verses.text: He said rightly "in the Lord," not "after the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:18
verses.text: for this is no rejoicing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:19
verses.text: These tribulations, he says, which are according to Christ bring joy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:20
verses.text: "To write the same things to you, to me indeed is not irksome, but for you it is safe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:21
verses.text: Beware of the dogs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:22
verses.text: Dost thou mark how he forbears to bring in the exhortation at the beginning? But after he had given them much commendation, after he had shown his admiration of them, then he does this, and again repeats his commendation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:23
verses.text: For this mode of speech seems to bear somewhat hard upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:24
verses.text: Wherefore he overshadows it on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:25
verses.text: But whom does he style "dogs"? There were at this place some of those, whom he hints at in all his Epistles, base and contemptible Jews, greedy of vile lucre and fond of power, who, desiring to draw aside many of the faithful, preached both Christianity and Judaism at the same time, corrupting the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:26
verses.text: As then they were not easily discernible, therefore he says, "beware of the dogs": the Jews are no longer children; once the Gentiles were called dogs, but now the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:27
verses.text: Wherefore? because as the Gentiles were strangers both to God and to Christ, even so are these become this now.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:28
verses.text: And he shows forth their shamelessness and violence, and their infinite distance from the relation of children, for that the Gentiles were once called "dogs," hear what the Canaanitish woman says, "Yea, Lord: for even the dogs eat of the crumbs which fall from their masters' table".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:29
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:30
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:31
verses.text: ) But that they might not have this advantage, since even dogs are at the table, he adds that, whereby he makes them aliens also, saying, "Beware of the evil workers"; he admirably expressed himself, "beware of the evil workers"; they work, he means, but for a bad end, and a work that is much worse than idleness, plucking up what is laid in goodly order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:32
verses.text: "Beware," he says, "of the concision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:33
verses.text: The rite of circumcision was venerable in the Jews' account, forasmuch as the Law itself gave way thereto, and the Sabbath was less esteemed than circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:34
verses.text: For that circumcision might be performed the Sabbath was broken; but that the Sabbath might be kept, circumcision was never broken; and mark, I pray, the dispensation of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:35
verses.text: This is found to be even more solemn than the Sabbath, as not being omitted at certain times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:36
verses.text: When then it is done away, much more is the Sabbath.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:37
verses.text: Wherefore Paul makes a concision of the name, and says, "Beware of the concision"; and he did not say "that circumcision is evil, that it is superfluous," lest he should strike the men with dismay, but he manages it more wisely, withdrawing them from the thing, but gratifying them with the word, nay, rather with the thing too, in a more serious way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:38
verses.text: But not so in the case of the Galatians, for since in that case the disease was great, he forthwith adopts the remedy of amputation with open front and with all boldness; but in this case, as they had done nothing of the sort, he vouchsafes them the gratification of the title, he casts out the others, and says, "Beware of the concision; for we are the circumcision"—how?—"who worship God in spirit, and have no confidence in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:39
verses.text: He said not that "we test the one circumcision and the other, which is the better of the two"; but he would not even allow it a share in the name; but what does he say? That that circumcision is "concision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:40
verses.text: Why? Because they do nothing but cut the flesh up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:41
verses.text: For when what is done is not of the law, it is nothing else than a concision and cutting up of the flesh; it was then either for this reason that he called it so, or because they were trying to cut the Church in twain; and we call the thing "cutting up" in those who do this at random, without aim and without skill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:42
verses.text: Now if you must seek circumcision, he says, you will find it among us, "who worship God in spirit," i-e: who worship spiritually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:43
verses.text: For answer me, which is superior, the soul or the body? Evidently the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:44
verses.text: Therefore that circumcision is also superior, or rather, no longer superior, but this is the only circumcision; for while the type stood, He rightly brought it forward in conjunction, writing, "For ye shall circumcise the foreskins of your hearts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:45
verses.text: (Jerem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:46
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:47
verses.text: ) In the same way in the Epistle to the Romans he does away with it, saying, "for he is not a Jew which is one outwardly, neither is that circumcision which is outward in the flesh; but he is a Jew which is one inwardly, and circumcision is that of the heart, in the spirit, not in the letter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:48
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:49
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:51
verses.text: ) And lastly, he takes from it the very name, "neither is it circumcision," he maintains; for the type while the reality is yet to come, is called this, but when the reality has come, it no longer retains the title.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:52
verses.text: As in delineation, a man has drawn a king in outline; so long as the colors are not put on we say, Lo, there is the king, but when they are added, the type is lost in the reality, and ceases to show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:53
verses.text: And he said not, "for the circumcision is in us," but "we are the circumcision," and justly; for this is the Man, the circumcision in virtue, this is really the Man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:54
verses.text: And he did not say, "For among them is the concision"; for they themselves are henceforth in a condition of ruin and of wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:55
verses.text: But no longer, says he, is circumcision performed in the body, but in the heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:56
verses.text: "And have no confidence," says he, "in the flesh; though I myself might have confidence even in the flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:58
verses.text: ) What does he call "confidence" here, and "in the flesh"? Boasting, boldness, a high tone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:59
verses.text: And he did well to add this; for if he had been of the Gentiles, and had condemned circumcision, and not only circumcision, but all those that adopted it out of place, it would have seemed that he was running it down, because he lacked the high ancestry of Judaism, as being a stranger to its solemn rites, and having no part therein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:60
verses.text: But as it is, he, who, though a sharer, yet blames them, will not therefore blame them as having no share in them, but as disowning them; not from ignorance, but most especially from acquaintance with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:61
verses.text: Accordingly observe what he says in his Epistle to the Galatians also; having been brought into a necessity of saying great things about himself, how even in these circumstances does he manifest nought but humility.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:62
verses.text: "For ye have heard, of my manner of life in time past," he says, "in the Jews' religion" (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:63
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:64
verses.text: ); and again here; "if any other man thinketh to have confidence in the flesh, I more".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:67
verses.text: And he immediately added, "a Hebrew of Hebrews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:68
verses.text: But "if any other man," says he, showing the necessity, showing that it was on their account that he spoke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:69
verses.text: "If ye have confidence," he says, I also say so, since I am silent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:70
verses.text: And observe the absence of all ungraciousness in the reproofs; by forbearing to do it by name, he gave even them the opportunity of retracing their steps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:71
verses.text: "If any one thinketh to have confidence"; and it was well to say "thinketh," either inasmuch as they really had no such confidence, or as that confidence was no real confidence, for all was by necessity, and not of choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:72
verses.text: "Circumcised on the eighth day"; and he sets down the first that wherein they chiefly boasted, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:73
verses.text: the ordinance of circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:74
verses.text: "Of the stock of Israel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:75
verses.text: He pointed out both these circumstances, that he was neither a proselyte, nor born of proselytes; for from his being circumcised on the eighth day, it follows that he was not a proselyte, and from his being of the stock of Israel, that he was not of proselyte parents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:76
verses.text: But that you may not imagine that he was of the stock of Israel as coming of the ten tribes, he says, "of the tribe of Benjamin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:77
verses.text: So that he was of the more approved portion, for the place of the priests was in the lot of this tribe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:78
verses.text: "An Hebrew of Hebrews".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:79
verses.text: Because he was not a proselyte, but from of old, of distinguished Jews; for he might have been of Israel, and yet not "an Hebrew of Hebrews," for many were already corrupting the matter, and were strangers to the language, being encircled by other nations; it is either this then, or the great superiority of his birth, that he shows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:80
verses.text: "According to the law a Pharisee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:81
verses.text: He is coming now to the circumstances dependent on his own will; for all those things were apart from the will, for his being circumcised was not of himself, nor that he was of the stock of Israel, nor that he was of the tribe of Benjamin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:82
verses.text: So that, even among these he has a larger share, even though there were really many who partook with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:83
verses.text: Where then are we to place the "rather"? Particularly herein that he was not a proselyte; for to be of the most distinguished tribe and sect, and this from his ancestors of old, was a thing which belonged not to many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:84
verses.text: But he comes to the things which are matters of choice, wherein we have the "rather".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:85
verses.text: "As touching the law, a Pharisee; as touching zeal, persecuting the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:86
verses.text: But this is not sufficient; for it is possible to be a Pharisee even, and yet not very zealous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:87
verses.text: But this also he adds; behold the "rather".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:88
verses.text: "According to righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:89
verses.text: It is possible, however, to be adventurous, or to act thus from ambition, and not out of zeal for the law, as the chief priests did.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:90
verses.text: Yet neither was this the case, but, "according to the righteousness which is in the law, found blameless".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:91
verses.text: If then both for purity of descent, and earnestness, and habits, and mode of life, I surpassed all, why have I renounced all those dignities, he asks, but because I found that the things of Christ are better, and better far? Wherefore he added; "howbeit what things were gain to me, these have I counted loss for Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:93
verses.text: )  Such a course of life, so strictly regulated, and entered upon from earliest childhood, such unblemished extraction, such dangers, plots, labors, forwardness, did Paul renounce, "counting them but loss," which before were "gain," that he might "win Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:94
verses.text: But we do not even contemn money, that we may "win Christ," but prefer to fail of the life to come rather than of the good things of the present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:95
verses.text: And yet this is nothing else than loss; for tell me now, let us examine in detail the conditions of riches, and see whether it be not loss accompanied with trouble, and without any gain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:96
verses.text: For tell me, what is the advantage of those stores of costly garments, what good do we gain when we are arrayed in them? None, nay, we are only losers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:97
verses.text: How so? Because even the poor man, in his cheap and threadbare clothing, does not bear the scorching in time of heat any wise worse than yourself; nay, rather he bears it better, for clothes that are threadbare and worn single allow more ease to the body, but not so with those which are new made, though they be finer than the spider's web.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:98
verses.text: Besides, you, from your excessive self-importance, wear even two and often three inner garments, and a cloak and girdle, and breeches too, but no one blames him if he wears but a single inner garment; so that he is the man that endures most easily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:99
verses.text: It is owing to this that we see rich men sweating, but the poor subject to nothing of the sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:100
verses.text: Since then his cheap clothing, which is sold for a trifle, answers the same or even a better purpose to him, and those clothes, which oblige a man to pay down much gold, do only the same thing, is not this great superabundance so much loss? For it has added nothing in respect of its use and service, but your purse is emptied of so much the more gold, and the same use and service.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:101
verses.text: You who have riches have purchased for a hundred pieces of gold, or even more, but the poor man for a trifling sum of silver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:102
verses.text: Do you perceive the loss? No, for your pride will not let you see it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:103
verses.text: Would you have us make out this account in the case of the gold ornaments too, which men put alike about their horses and their wives? For besides the other evils, the possession of money makes fools of men; they account their wives and horses to be worthy of the same honor, and the ornamentation of both is the same; and they would make themselves finer by the same means as the very beasts that carry them, or as the very skins of the awnings, wherein they are borne.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:104
verses.text: What now is the use of decking out a mule or a horse with gold? or the lady, that has such a weight of gold and jewels about her person, what does she gain? "But the golden ornaments are never worn out," he answers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:105
verses.text: Assuredly this also is said that in the baths and many places both precious stones and gold ornaments lose much of their value.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:106
verses.text: But be it so, and grant that they are not injured, tell me, what is the gain? And how is it when they drop out, and are lost? is there no loss sustained? And how when they draw down upon you envy and intrigues? is there no loss then? For when they do the wearer no good, but rather inflame the eyes of the envious, and act as an incitement to the robber, do they not become loss? And again, say, when a man may use them for a serviceable purpose, but is unable on account of the extravagance of his wife, and is obliged to starve and to stint himself, that he may see her arrayed in gold, is it not a matter of loss? For it was on this account that goods have their name from use, not that we should use them thus like goldsmiths' samples, but that we should do some good therewith; so then when love of gold does not allow this, is not the whole thing loss? for he that dares not use them forbears the use as if they were another's property, and there is no use of them in any way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:107
verses.text: Again, how is it when we erect splendid and spacious mansions, decorated with columns, marbles, porticos, arcades, and in every possible way, setting images and statues everywhere? Many indeed even call demons out of these, i-e: the images, but let us omit the examination of those points.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:108
verses.text: What too is the meaning of the gilded ceiling? Does it not supply the same need as to him, whose house is on a moderate scale? "But there is great delight in it," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:109
verses.text: Yes, for the first or second day, and afterwards, none at all, but it stands merely for nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:110
verses.text: For if the sun does not strike us with wonder, from its being customary, much more do works of art fail, and we only look at them like things of clay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:111
verses.text: For tell me, what does a range of pillars contribute to make your dwelling superior to others, or the finest statues, or the gilding spread over the wall? Nothing; rather, these come of luxury and insolence, and overweening pride and folly; for everything there ought to be necessary and useful, not superfluous things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:112
verses.text: Do you see that the thing is loss? Do you see that it is superfluous and unprofitable? for if it supplies no further use or delight, (and it "does," in the course of time, bring satiety,) it is nothing else than loss, and vainglory is the hindrance, which will not let us see this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:113
verses.text: Did Paul then forsake those things which he "counted gain," and shall not we even quit our loss, for Christ's sake? How long shall we be riveted to the earth? How long till we shall look up to heaven? Do ye not mark the aged, what little perception they have of the past? Do ye not mark those that are finishing their course, both men in age, and men in youth? Do ye not see persons in the midst of life bereft of them? Why are we so wedded to unstable objects? Why are we linked to things that are shifting? How long before we lay hold of the things that last? What would not the old give, were it granted them to divest themselves of their old age? How irrational then to wish to return to our former youth, and gladly to give everything for the sake of this, that we might become younger, and yet when it is ours to receive a youth that knows no old age, a youth too, which, joined with great riches, hath far more of spirit, to be unwilling to give up a little trifle, but to hold fast things that contribute not a whit to the present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:114
verses.text: They can never rescue you from death, they have no power to drive away disease, to stay old age, or any one of those events, which happen by necessity and according to the law of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:115
verses.text: And do you still hold to them? Tell me, what do you gain? Drunkenness, gluttony, pleasures contrary to nature and various in kind, which are far worse torturers than the hardest masters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:116
verses.text: These are the advantages which we gain from riches, nor is there one besides, since we are not so minded, for if we had had the mind, we might have won heaven itself for our inheritance by our riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:117
verses.text: "So then riches are good," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:118
verses.text: It is not riches, but the will of the possessor that effects this, for because it is the will that does this, it is in the power even of a poor man to win heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:119
verses.text: For, as I have often said, God does not regard the amount of the gifts, but the will of the givers; it is possible even for one in poverty, who has given but little, to bear off all, for God requires a measure proportioned to our ability, neither will riches secure heaven to us, nor poverty, hell; but a good or a bad will, either one or the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:120
verses.text: This then let us correct, this let us repossess, this let us regulate, and all will then be easy to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:121
verses.text: For as the artificer works the wood the same, whether his axe be of iron or of gold, or rather he does it the better with an implement of iron, so here too, the straight path of virtue is more easily kept in a state of poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:122
verses.text: For touching riches we read, "It is easier for a camel to go through a needle's eye, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:123
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:124
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:125
verses.text: ) But He has made no such declarations about poverty; nay, the very reverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:126
verses.text: "Sell thy goods, and give to the poor, and come follow Me" (v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:127
verses.text: ); as if the act of following were to spring from the selling.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:128
verses.text: Never then let us flee from poverty as an evil, for it is the procurer of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:129
verses.text: Again, let us never follow riches as a good; for they are the ruin of such as walk unwarily, but in everything directing our eyes to God, let us, as occasion requires, use those gifts which He has vouchsafed us, both strength of body, and abundance of money, and every other gift; for it is unnatural that we, who have our being for Him, should make these things serviceable to others, yet not to Him who has made us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:130
verses.text: He formed thine eye: make it serviceable to Him, not to the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:131
verses.text: But how serviceable to Him? By contemplating His creatures and praising and glorifying Him, and by withdrawing it from all gaze at women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:132
verses.text: Did He make thy hands? Preserve them for His use, not for the devil, not putting them out for robbery and rapine, but for His commandments and for good deeds, for earnest prayers, for holding out help to the fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:133
verses.text: Hath He made thine ears? Give these to Him, and not to effeminate strains nor to disgraceful tales; but "let all thy communication be in the law of the Most High".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:134
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:135
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:136
verses.text: ) For "stand," he says, "in the multitude of the elders, and whoever is wise, cleave unto him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:137
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:138
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:139
verses.text: ) Did he make thy mouth? Let it do nought that is displeasing to Him, but sing psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:140
verses.text: "Let no corrupt speech proceed out of your mouth," says the Apostle, "but such as is good for edifying as the need may be, that it may give grace to them that hear" (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:141
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:142
verses.text: ); for edification and not for subversion, for fair words and not for evil speaking and plotting against other, but the very opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:143
verses.text: He hath made thy feet, not that thou shouldest run to do evil, but to do good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:144
verses.text: He made thy belly, not that thou shouldest cram it to bursting, but to practice lessons of wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:145
verses.text: For the production of children, He implanted desire in thy mind, not for fornication, nor for adultery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:146
verses.text: He gave thee understanding, not to make of thee a blasphemer or a reviler, but that thou mightest be without falsehood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:147
verses.text: He gave us both money to be used on fitting occasion, and strength likewise to be used on fitting occasion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:148
verses.text: He instituted arts, that our present state of existence might be held together by them, not that we should separate ourselves from spiritual things, not that we should devote ourselves to the base arts but to the necessary ones, that we might minister to one another's good, and not that we should plot one against another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:149
verses.text: He gave us a roof, that it might afford shelter from the rain, and no more, not that it should be decked out with gold, while the poor man perishes with hunger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:150
verses.text: He gave clothing to cover us, not to make a display withal, not that things like these should have much gold lavished upon them, and that Christ should perish naked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:151
verses.text: He gave you a place of shelter, not that you should keep it to yourself, but to offer it to others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:152
verses.text: He gave thee land, not that, cutting off the chief portion of it, you should spend the good gifts of God upon harlots, and dancers, and actors, and flute players, and harp players, but upon those that hunger and are in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:153
verses.text: He gave you the sea to sail on, that you might not be wearied with journeying, not that you should pry into its depths, and bring up thence precious stones and all the other things of the same kind, nor that you should make this your business.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:154
verses.text: "Why then are there precious stones?" he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:155
verses.text: Nay, do you tell me why these stones are such, and why one class are regarded as of great value, while the others are more useful? For these may be conducive to building, but those to no purpose; and these are stronger than those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:156
verses.text: "But they," he says, "produce a beautiful effect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:157
verses.text: How so? it is a matter of fancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:158
verses.text: Are they whiter? No, they are not whiter than pure white marble, nor nearly equal to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:159
verses.text: But are they stronger? Not even this can be said for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:160
verses.text: Well then, are they more useful? are they larger? Not even this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:161
verses.text: Whence then are they so admired, save from fancy? For if they are neither more beautiful, (for we shall find others more shining and more white,) nor useful, nor stronger, whence came they to be so admired? Was it not from mere fancy? Why then did God give them? They were not His gift, but it is your own imagination that they are anything great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:162
verses.text: "How is it, then," he answers, "that even the Scripture shows admiration of them?" So far it addresses itself to your fancy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:163
verses.text: As a master too in talking to a child often admires the same object as it does, when he desires to attract and engage it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:164
verses.text: Why do you aim at finery in your clothing? He clothed thee with a garment and with sandals.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:165
verses.text: But where is there any reason for these things? "The judgments of God," he says, "are more to be desired than gold; yea than much fine gold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:166
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:167
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:168
verses.text: ) These, beloved, are of no use.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:169
verses.text: Had they been of use, he would not have bidden us despise them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:170
verses.text: And for Holy Scripture, it speaks with reference to our notion, and this too is an instance of God's lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:171
verses.text: "Why then," he asks, "did He give purple and the like?" These things are products of God's gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:172
verses.text: For He has willed by other things also to show forth His own riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:173
verses.text: And He gave you corn too by itself; but from this you make many things, cakes and sweetmeats, of every sort and variety, having much enjoyment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:174
verses.text: Pleasure and vainglory give rise to all these inventions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:175
verses.text: It pleased you to set them before everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:176
verses.text: For if a foreigner or a rustic, who was ignorant of the land, should put the question, and, seeing your admiration, were to say, "Why do you admire these?" What have you to say? that they are fair to look at? But not so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:177
verses.text: Let us then give up such notions; let us lay hold of the things that are truly real.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:178
verses.text: These are not, but simply pass away, only flowing past like a river.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 11:179
verses.text: Wherefore I charge you, let us take our stand upon the rock, that we both escape being easily turned about, and that we may obtain the good things to come, by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:1
verses.text: Homily XI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:2
verses.text: Philippians iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:3
verses.text: –  "Howbeit what things were gain to me, these have I counted loss for Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:4
verses.text: Yea verily, and I counted all things to be loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may gain Christ and be found in Him, not having a righteousness of mine own, even that which is of the law, but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness which is of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:5
verses.text: In our contests with heretics, we must make the attack with minds in vigor, that they may be able to give exact attention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:6
verses.text: I will therefore begin nay present discourse where the last ended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:7
verses.text: And what was that? Having enumerated every Jewish boast, both those from his birth, and those that were from choice, he added, "Howbeit, what things were gain to me, these have I counted to be loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord; for whom I suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may gain Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:8
verses.text: Here the heretics spring to their attack: for even this comes of the wisdom of the Spirit, to suggest to them hopes of victory, that they may undertake the fight.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:9
verses.text: For if it had been spoken plainly, they would have acted here as they have done in other places, they would have blotted out the words, they would have denied the Scripture, when they were unable at all to look it in the face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:10
verses.text: But as in the case of fishes, that which can take them is concealed so that they may swim up, and does not lie open to view; this in truth hath come to pass here too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:11
verses.text: The Law, they say, is called "dung" by Paul, it is called "loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:12
verses.text: He says, it was not possible to gain Christ except I "suffered" this "loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:13
verses.text: All these things induced the heretics to accept this passage, thinking it to be favorable to them: but when they had taken it, then did he enclose them on all sides with his nets.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:14
verses.text: For what do they themselves say? Lo! the Law is "loss," is "dung"; how then do ye say that it is of God?  But these very words are favorable to the Law, and how they are so, shall be hence manifest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:15
verses.text: Let us attend accurately to his very words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:16
verses.text: He said not, The Law is loss: but "I counted it loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:17
verses.text: But when he spake of gain, he said not, I counted them, but "they were gain".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:18
verses.text: But when he spake of loss he said, "I counted": and this rightly; for the former was naturally so, but the latter became so, from my opinion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:19
verses.text: "What then? Is it not so?" says he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:20
verses.text: It is loss for Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:21
verses.text: And how has the law become gain? And it was not counted gain, but was so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:22
verses.text: For consider how great a thing it was, to bring men, brutalized in their nature, to the shape of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:23
verses.text: If the law had not been, grace would not have been given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:24
verses.text: Wherefore? Because it became a sort of bridge; for when it was impossible to mount on high from a state of great abasement, a ladder was formed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:25
verses.text: But he who has ascended has no longer need of the ladder; yet he does not despise it, but is even grateful to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:26
verses.text: For it has placed him in such a position, as no longer to require it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:27
verses.text: And yet for this very reason, that he doth not require it, it is just that he should acknowledge his obligation, for he could not fly up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:28
verses.text: And thus is it with the Law, it hath led us up on high; wherefore it was gain, but for the future we esteem it loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:29
verses.text: How? Not because it is loss, but because grace is far greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:30
verses.text: For as a poor man, that was in hunger, as long as he has silver, escapes hunger, but when he finds gold, and it is not allowable to keep both, considers it loss to retain the former, and having thrown it away, takes the gold coin; so also here; not because the silver is loss, for it is not; but because it is impossible to take both at once, but it is necessary to leave one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:31
verses.text: Not the Law then is loss, but for a man to cleave to the Law, and desert Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:32
verses.text: Wherefore it is then loss when it leads us away from Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:33
verses.text: But if it sends us on to Him, it is no longer so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:34
verses.text: For this cause he saith "loss for Christ"; if for Christ, it is not so naturally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:35
verses.text: But why doth not the Law suffer us to come to Christ? For this very cause, he tells us, was it given.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:36
verses.text: And Christ is the fulfilling of the Law, and Christ is the end of the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:37
verses.text: It doth suffer us if we will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:38
verses.text: "For Christ is the end of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:39
verses.text: He who obeyeth the Law, leaves the Law itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:40
verses.text: It suffers, if we take heed to it, but if we do not take heed, it suffers not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:41
verses.text: "Yea verily, and I have counted all things but loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:42
verses.text: Why, he means, do I say this of the Law? Is not the world good? Is not the present life good? but if they draw me away from Christ, I count these things loss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:43
verses.text: Why? "for the excellency of the knowledge of Jesus Christ my Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:44
verses.text: For when the sun hath appeared, it is loss to sit by a candle: so that the loss comes by comparison, by the superiority of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:45
verses.text: You see that Paul makes a comparison from superiority, not from diversity of kind; for that which is superior, is superior to somewhat of like nature to itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:46
verses.text: So that he shows the connection of that knowledge by the same means, by which he draws the superiority from the comparison.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:47
verses.text: "For whom I suffered the loss of all things, and do count them dung, that I may gain Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:48
verses.text: It is not yet manifest, whether he speaks of the Law, for it is likely that he applies it to the things of this world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:49
verses.text: For when he says, "the things which were gain to me, those I have counted loss for Christ; yea verily," he adds, "I count all things loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:50
verses.text: Although he said all things, yet it is things present; and if you wish it to be the Law too, not even so is it insulted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:51
verses.text: For dung comes from wheat, and the strength of the wheat is the dung, I mean, the chaff.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:52
verses.text: But as the dung was useful in its former state, so that we gather it together with the wheat, and had there been no dung, there would have been no wheat, thus too is it with the Law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:53
verses.text: Seest thou, how everywhere he calls it "loss," not in itself, but for Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:54
verses.text: "Yea verily, and I count all things but loss".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:55
verses.text: Wherefore again? "For the excellency of the knowledge (of Him), for whom I suffered the loss of all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:56
verses.text: Again, "wherefore too I count all things to be loss, that I may gain Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:57
verses.text: See how, from every point, he lays hold of Christ as his foundation, and suffers not the Law to be anywhere exposed, or receive a blow, but guards it on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:58
verses.text: "And that I may be found in Him, not having a righteousness of mine own, even that which is of the Law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:59
verses.text: If he who had righteousness, ran to this other righteousness because his own was nothing, how much rather ought they, who have it not, to run to Him? And he well said, "a righteousness of mine own," not that which I gained by labor and toil, but that which I found from grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:60
verses.text: If then he who was so excellent is saved by grace, much more are you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:61
verses.text: For since it was likely they would say that the righteousness which comes from toil is the greater, he shows that it is dung in comparison with the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:62
verses.text: For otherwise I, who was so excellent in it, would not have cast it away, and run to the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:63
verses.text: But what is that other? That which is from the faith of God, i-e: it too is given by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:64
verses.text: This is the righteousness of God; this is altogether a gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:65
verses.text: And the gifts of God far exceed those worthless good deeds, which are due to our own diligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:66
verses.text: But what is "By faith that I may know Him"? So then knowledge is through faith, and without faith it is impossible to know Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:67
verses.text: Why how? Through it we must "know the power of His resurrection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:68
verses.text: For what reason can demonstrate to us the Resurrection? None, but faith only.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:69
verses.text: For if the resurrection of Christ, who was according to the flesh, is known by faith, how can the generation of the Word of God be comprehended by reasoning? For the resurrection is less than the generation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:70
verses.text: Why? Because of that there have been many examples, but of this none ever; for many dead arose before Christ, though after their resurrection they died, but no one was ever born of a virgin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:71
verses.text: If then we must comprehend by faith that which is inferior to the generation according to the flesh, how can that which is far greater, immeasurably and incomparably greater, be comprehended by reason? These things make the righteousness; this must we believe that He was able to do, but how He was able we cannot prove.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:72
verses.text: For from faith is the fellowship of His sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:73
verses.text: But how? Had we not believed, neither should we have suffered: had we not believed, that "if we endure with Him, we shall also reign with Him" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:74
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:75
verses.text: ), we should not have endured the sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:76
verses.text: Both the generation and the resurrection is comprehended by faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:77
verses.text: Seest thou, that faith must not be absolutely, but through good works; for he especially believes that Christ hath risen, who in like sort gives himself up to dangers, who hath fellowship with Him in His sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:78
verses.text: For he hath fellowship with Him who rose again, with Him who liveth; wherefore he saith, "And may be found in Him, not having a righteousness of mine own, even that which is of the law, but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith: that I may know Him, and the power of His resurrection, and the fellowship of His sufferings, becoming conformed unto His death; if by any means I may attain unto the resurrection from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:79
verses.text: He saith, being made conformable unto His death, i-e: having fellowship; whereas He suffered from men, thus I too; wherefore he said, "becoming conformed" and again in another place, "and fill up on my part that which is lacking of the afflictions of Christ in my flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:80
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:81
