verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:82
verses.text: ) That is, these persecutions and sufferings work the image of His death, for He sought not His own, but the good of many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:83
verses.text: Therefore persecutions, and afflictions, and straits, ought not to disturb you, but ought even to make you glad, because through them we are "conformed to His death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:84
verses.text: As if he had said, We are molded to His likeness; as he says in another place, where he writeth, "bearing about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:85
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:86
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:87
verses.text: ) And this too comes from great faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:88
verses.text: For we not only believe that He arose, but that after His resurrection also He hath great power: wherefore we travel the same road which He travelled, i-e: we become brethren to Him in this respect also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:89
verses.text: As if he had said, We become Christ's in this respect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:90
verses.text: O how great is the dignity of sufferings! We believe that we become "conformed to His death" through sufferings! For as in baptism, we were "buried with the likeness of His death," so here, with His death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:91
verses.text: There did he rightly say, "The likeness of His death" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:92
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:94
verses.text: ), for there we died not entirely, we died not in the flesh, to the body, but to sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:95
verses.text: Since then a death is spoken of, and a death; but He indeed died in the body, whilst we died to sin, and there the Man died which He assumed, who was in our flesh, but here the man of sin; for this cause he saith, "the likeness of His death," but here, no longer the likeness of His death, but His death itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:96
verses.text: For Paul, in his persecutions, no longer died to sin, but in his very body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:97
verses.text: Wherefore, he endured the same death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:98
verses.text: "If by any means," saith he, "I may attain unto the resurrection from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:99
verses.text: What sayest thou? All men will have a share in that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:100
verses.text: "For we shall not all sleep, but we shall all be changed" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:101
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:102
verses.text: ), and shall all share not only in the Resurrection, but in incorruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:103
verses.text: Some indeed to honor, but others as a means of punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:104
verses.text: If therefore all have a share in the Resurrection, and not in the Resurrection only, but also in incorruption, how said he, "If by any means I may attain," as if about to share in some especial thing? "For this cause," saith he, "I endure these things, if by any means I may attain unto the resurrection from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:105
verses.text: For if thou hadst not died, thou wouldest not arise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:106
verses.text: What is it then? Some great thing seems here to be hinted at.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:107
verses.text: So great was it, that he dared not openly assert it, but saith, "If by any means".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:108
verses.text: I have believed in Him and His resurrection, nay, moreover, I suffer for Him, yet I am unable to be confident concerning the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:109
verses.text: What resurrection doth he here mention? That which leads to Christ Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:110
verses.text: I said, that I believed in "Him, and in the power of His resurrection," and that I "have fellowship with His sufferings," and that I "become conformed to His death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:111
verses.text: Yet after all these things I am by no means confident; as he said elsewhere, "Let him that thinketh he standeth, take heed lest he fall".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:112
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:113
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:114
verses.text: ) And again, "I fear lest by any means, after that I have preached to others, I myself should be rejected".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:115
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:116
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:117
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:118
verses.text: "Not that I have already obtained, or am already made perfect: but I press on, if so be that I may apprehend that for which also I was apprehended by Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:119
verses.text: "Not that I have already obtained".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:120
verses.text: What means "already obtained"? He speaks of the prize, but if he who had endured such sufferings, he who was persecuted, he "who had in him the dying of the Lord Jesus," was not yet confident about that resurrection, what can we say? What meaneth, "if I may apprehend"? What he before said, "If I may attain to the resurrection of the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:121
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:122
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:123
verses.text: ) If I may apprehend, he saith, His resurrection; i-e: if I may be able to endure so great things, if I may be able to imitate Him, if I may be able to become conformed to Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:124
verses.text: For example, Christ suffered many things, He was spit upon, He was stricken, was scourged, at last He suffered what things he suffered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:125
verses.text: This is the entire course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:126
verses.text: Through all these things it is needful that men should endure the whole contest, and so come to His resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:127
verses.text: Or he means this, if I am thought worthy to attain the glorious resurrection, which is a matter of confidence, in order to His resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:128
verses.text: For if I am able to endure all the contests, I shall be able also to have His resurrection, and to rise with glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:129
verses.text: For not as yet, saith he, am I worthy, but "I press on, if so be that I may apprehend".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:130
verses.text: My life is still one of contest, I am still far from the end, I am still distant from the prize, still I run, still I pursue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:131
verses.text: And He said not, I run, but "I pursue".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:132
verses.text: For you know with what eagerness a man pursues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:133
verses.text: He sees no one, he thrusts aside with great violence all who would interrupt his pursuit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:134
verses.text: He collects together his mind, and sight, and strength, and soul, and body, looking to nothing else than the prize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:135
verses.text: But if Paul, who so pursued, who had suffered so many things, yet saith, "if I may attain," what should we say, who have relaxed our efforts? Then to show that the thing is of debt, he saith, "For which also I was apprehended by Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:136
verses.text: I was, he saith, of the number of the lost, I gasped for breath, I was nigh dead, God apprehended me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:137
verses.text: For He pursued us, when we fled from Him, with all speed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:138
verses.text: So that he points out all those things; for the words, "I was apprehended," show the earnestness of Him who wishes to apprehend us, and our great aversion to Him, our wandering, our flight from Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:139
verses.text: So that we are liable for a vast debt, and no one grieves, no one weeps, no one groans, all having returned to their former state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:140
verses.text: For as before the appearance of Christ we fled from God, so now also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:141
verses.text: For we can flee from God, not in place, for He is everywhere; and hear the Prophet, when he says, "Whither shall I go from Thy Spirit, or whither shall I flee from Thy presence"? (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:142
verses.text: cxxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:143
verses.text: ) How then can we flee from God? Even as we can become distant from God, even as we can be removed afar off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:144
verses.text: "They that are far from Thee," it says, "shall perish".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:145
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:146
verses.text: lxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:147
verses.text: ) And again, "Have not your iniquities separated between Me and you?" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:148
verses.text: lix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:149
verses.text: ) How then comes this removal, how comes this separation? In purpose and soul: for it cannot be in place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:150
verses.text: For how could one fly from Him who is everywhere present? The sinner then flies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:151
verses.text: This is what the Scripture saith, "The wicked fleeth when no man pursueth him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:152
verses.text: (Prov.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:153
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:154
verses.text: ) We eagerly fly from God, although He always pursueth us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:155
verses.text: The Apostle hasted, that he might be near Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:156
verses.text: We haste, that we may be far off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:157
verses.text: Are not these things then worthy of lamentation? Are they not worthy of tears? Whither fliest thou, wretched and miserable man? Whither fliest thou from thy Life and thy Salvation? If thou fly from God, with whom wilt thou take refuge? If thou fly from the Light, whither wilt thou cast thine eyes? If thou fly from thy Life, whence wilt thou henceforth live? Let us fly from the enemy of our Salvation! Whensoever we sin we fly from God, we are as runaways, we depart to a foreign land, as he who consumed his paternal goods and departed into a foreign land, who wasted all his father's substance, and lived in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:158
verses.text: We too have substance from our Father; and what is this? He hath freed us from our sins; He hath freely given to us power, strength for works of virtue; He hath freely given to us readiness, patience; He hath freely given to us the Holy Ghost in our baptism; if we waste these things we shall henceforth be in want.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:159
verses.text: For as the sick, as long as they are troubled with fevers, and badness of their juices, are unable to arise or work, or do anything, but if any one sets them free, and brings them to health, if they then work not, this comes from their own sloth; thus too is it with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:160
verses.text: For the disease was heavy and the fever excessive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:161
verses.text: And we lay not upon a bed, but upon wickedness itself, cast away in crime, as on a dunghill, full of sores, and evil odors, squalid, wasting away, more like ghosts than men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:162
verses.text: Evil spirits encompassed us about, the Prince of this world deriding and assaulting us; the Only-Begotten Son of God came, sent forth the rays of His Presence, and straightway dispelled the darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:163
verses.text: The King, who is on His Father's throne, came to us, having left His Father's throne.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:164
verses.text: And when I say having left, think not of any removal, for He filleth the heavens and the earth, but I speak of the economy; He came to an enemy, who hated Him, who turned himself away, who could not endure to behold Him, who blasphemed Him every day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:165
verses.text: He saw him lying on a dunghill, eaten with worms, afflicted with fever and hunger, having every sort of disease; for both fever vexed him, which is evil desire; and inflammation lay heavy on him, this is pride; and gnawing hunger had hold of him, which is covetousness; and putrefying sores on every side, for this is fornication; and blindness of eyes, which is idolatry; and dumbness, and madness, which is to worship stocks and stones, and address them; and great deformity, for wickedness is this, foul to behold, and a most heavy disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:166
verses.text: And he saw us speaking more foolishly than the mad, and calling stocks our God, and stones likewise; He saw us in such great guilt, he did not reject us; was not wroth, turned not away, hated us not, for He was a Master, and could not hate His own creation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:167
verses.text: But what does he do? As a most excellent physician, He prepareth medicines of great price, and Himself tastes them first.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:168
verses.text: For He Himself first followed after virtue, and thus gave it to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:169
verses.text: And He first gave us the washing, like some antidote, and thus we vomited up all our guilt, and all things took their flight at once, and our inflammation ceased, and our fever was quenched, and our sores were dried up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:170
verses.text: For all the evils which are from covetousness, and anger, and all the rest, were dissipated by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:171
verses.text: Our eyes were opened, our ears were opened, our tongue spake holy words: our soul received strength, our body received such beauty and bloom, as it is like that he who is born a son of God should have from the grace of the Spirit; such glory as it is like that the new-born son of a king should have, nurtured in purple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:172
verses.text: Alas! How great nobility did He confer on us!  We were born, we were nurtured, why do we again fly from our Benefactor? He then, who hath done all these things, giveth us strength too, for it was not possible, for a soul bowed down by the disease to endure it, did not He Himself give us the strength.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:173
verses.text: He gave us remission of our sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:174
verses.text: We devoured all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:175
verses.text: He gave us strength, we wasted it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:176
verses.text: He gave us grace, we quenched it; and how? we consumed it upon nought that was fitting, we used it for no useful end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:177
verses.text: These things have destroyed us, and what is more dreadful than all, when we are in a foreign country, and feeding on husks, we say not, Let us return to our Father, and say, "We have sinned against Heaven, and against Thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:178
verses.text: (Luke xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:179
verses.text: ) And that too, when we have so loving a Father, who eagerly desires our return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:180
verses.text: If we will only return to Him, He does not even bear to call in question our former deeds, only let us quit them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:181
verses.text: It is sufficient apology with Him, that we have returned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:182
verses.text: Not only He Himself calls not in question, but if another does so, He stops his mouth, though the accuser be one of good repute.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:183
verses.text: Let us return! How long do we stand afar off? Let us perceive our dishonor, let us be sensible of our vileness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 12:184
verses.text: Sin makes us swine, sin brings famine to the soul; let us regain ourselves, and be sober again, and return to our former high birth, that we may obtain the good things which are to come, in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father together with the Holy Spirit be glory, might, honor, now and ever and world without end.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:2
verses.text: Philippians iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:3
verses.text: ,  "Brethren, I count not myself yet to have apprehended: but one thing I do, forgetting the things which are behind, and stretching forward to the things which are before, I press on toward the goal unto the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:4
verses.text: Nothing so renders our real excellences vain and puffs them away, as to be remembering the good deeds we have done; for this produces two evils, it both renders us remiss, and raises us to haughtiness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:5
verses.text: Wherefore see how Paul, since he knew our nature to be easily inclined to remissness, though he had given great praise to the Philippians, now subdues their mind by many other things above, but chiefly by his present words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:6
verses.text: And what are they? "Brethren, I count not myself to have apprehended".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:7
verses.text: But if Paul had not as yet apprehended, and is not confident about the Resurrection and things to come, hardly should they be so, who have not attained the smallest proportion of his excellence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:8
verses.text: That is, I consider that I have not as yet apprehended all virtue, as if one were speaking of a runner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:9
verses.text: Not as yet, saith he, have I completed all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:10
verses.text: And if in another place he saith, "I have fought the good fight" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:11
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:12
verses.text: ), but here, "I count myself not as yet to have apprehended"; any one who reads carefully will well know the reason both of those, and of the present words; (for it is not necessary to dwell continually on the same point;) and that he spoke these words at a much earlier date, but the others near his death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:13
verses.text: But I am solely engaged on "one thing," says he, "in stretching forward to the things which are before".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:14
verses.text: But "one thing," says he, "forgetting the things which are behind, and stretching forward to the things which are before, I press on toward the goal unto the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:15
verses.text: For what made him reach forward unto the things which are before, was his forgetting the things that are behind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:16
verses.text: He then, who thinks that all is accomplished, and that nothing is wanting to him for the perfecting of virtue, may cease running, as having apprehended all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:17
verses.text: But he who thinks that he is still distant from the goal, will never cease running.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:18
verses.text: This then we should always consider, even though we have wrought ten thousand good deeds; for if Paul, after ten thousand deaths, after so many dangers, considered this, how much more should we? For I fainted not, saith he, although I availed not, after running so much; nor did I despair, but I still run, I still strive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:19
verses.text: This thing only I consider, that I may in truth advance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:20
verses.text: Thus too we should act, we should forget our successes, and throw them behind us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:21
verses.text: For the runner reckons not up how many circuits he hath finished, but how many are left.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:22
verses.text: We too should reckon up, not how far we are advanced in virtue, but how much remains for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:23
verses.text: For what doth that which is finished profit us, when that which is deficient is not added? Moreover he did not say, I do not reckon up, but I do not even remember.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:24
verses.text: For we thus become eager, when we apply all diligence to what is left, when we give to oblivion everything else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:25
verses.text: "Stretching forward," saith he; before we arrive, we strive to obtain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:26
verses.text: For he that stretches forward is one who, though his feet are running, endeavors to outstrip them with the rest of his body, stretching himself towards the front, and reaching out his hands, that he may accomplish somewhat more of the course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:27
verses.text: And this comes from great eagerness, from much warmth; thus the runner should run with great earnestness, with so great eagerness, without relaxation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:28
verses.text: As far as one who so runs differs from him who lies supine, so far doth Paul differ from us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:29
verses.text: He died daily, he was approved daily, there was no season, there was no time in which his course advanced not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:30
verses.text: He wished not to take, but to snatch the prize; for in this way we may take it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:31
verses.text: He who giveth the prize standeth on high, the prize is laid up on high.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:32
verses.text: See how great a distance this is that must be run over! See how great an ascent! Thither we must fly up with the wings of the Spirit, otherwise it is impossible to surmount this height.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:33
verses.text: Thither must we go with the body, for it is allowed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:34
verses.text: "For our citizenship is in heaven" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:35
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:36
verses.text: ), there is the prize; seest thou the runners, how they live by rule, how they touch nothing that relaxes their strength, how they exercise themselves every day in the palaestra, under a master, and by rule? Imitate them, or rather exhibit even greater eagerness, for the prizes are not equal: many are those who would hinder you; live by rule: many are the things which relax your strength; make its feet agile: for it is possible so to do, it comes not naturally, but by our will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:37
verses.text: Let us bring it to lightness, lest our swiftness of foot be hindered by the weight of other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:38
verses.text: Teach thy feet to be sure, for there are many slippery places, and if thou fallest, straightway thou losest much.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:39
verses.text: But yet if thou fall, rise up again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:40
verses.text: Even thus mayst thou obtain the victory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:41
verses.text: Never attempt slippery things, and thou wilt not fall; walk upon firm ground, up with thy head, up with thine eyes; these commands the trainers give to those who run.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:42
verses.text: Thus thy strength is supported; but if thou stoopest downward, thou fallest, thou art relaxed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:43
verses.text: Look upward, where the prize is; the sight of the prize increaseth the determination of our will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:44
verses.text: The hope of taking it suffereth not to perceive the toils, it maketh the distance appear short.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:45
verses.text: And what is this prize? No palm branch; but what? The kingdom of heaven, everlasting rest, glory together with Christ, the inheritance, brotherhood, ten thousand good things, which it is impossible to name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:46
verses.text: It is impossible to describe the beauty of that prize; he who hath it alone knoweth it, and he who is about to receive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:47
verses.text: It is not of gold, it is not set with jewels, it is far more precious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:48
verses.text: Gold is mire, in comparison with that prize, precious stones are mere bricks in comparison with its beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:49
verses.text: If thou hast this, and takest thy departure to heaven, thou wilt be able to walk there with great honor; the angels will reverence thee, when thou bearest this prize, with much confidence wilt thou approach them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:50
verses.text: "In Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:51
verses.text: See the humility of his mind; this I do, saith he, "in Christ Jesus," for it is impossible without an impulse from Him to pass over so vast an interval: we have need of much aid, of a mighty alliance; He hath willed that thou shouldest struggle below, on high He crowns thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:52
verses.text: Not as in this world; the crown is not here, where the contest is; but the crown is in that bright place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:53
verses.text: See ye not, even here, that the most honored of the wrestlers and charioteers are not crowned in the course below, but the king calls them up, and crowns them there? Thus too is it here, in heaven thou receivest the prize.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:55
verses.text: "Let us, therefore, as many as be perfect, be thus minded," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:56
verses.text: "And if in anything ye are otherwise minded, even this shall God reveal unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:57
verses.text: What sort of thing? That we should "forget the things which are behind".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:58
verses.text: Wherefore it belongs to him who is perfect not to consider himself perfect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:59
verses.text: How therefore sayest thou, "as many as are perfect"? For tell me, are we minded as thou art? For if thou hast not attained nor art perfected, how dost thou command those that are perfect to be so minded as thou art, who art not yet perfect? Yea, for this, saith he, is perfection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:60
verses.text: And "if ye are in anything otherwise minded, even this shall God reveal unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:61
verses.text: That is, if any one considers that he has attained all excellence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:62
verses.text: He puts them on their guard, not by speaking directly, but what saith he? "If in anything ye are otherwise minded, even this shall God reveal unto you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:63
verses.text: See how humbly he saith this! God shall teach you, i-e: God shall persuade you, not teach you; for Paul was teaching, but God shall lead them on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:64
verses.text: And he said not, shall lead you on, but "shall reveal," that this may rather seem to spring from ignorance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:65
verses.text: These words were spoken not concerning doctrines, but concerning perfection of life, and our not considering ourselves to be perfect, for he who considers that he hath apprehended all, hath nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:66
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:67
verses.text: "Only, whereunto we have already attained, by that same rule let us walk, let us mind the same thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:68
verses.text: "Only, whereunto we have attained".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:69
verses.text: What means this? Let us hold fast, he saith, that in which we have succeeded; love, concord, and peace: for in this we have succeeded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:70
verses.text: "Whereto we have attained: to walk by the same rule, to mind the same thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:71
verses.text: "Whereunto we have attained," i-e: in this we have already succeeded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:72
verses.text: Seest thou, that he wills that his precepts should be a rule to us? And a rule admits neither addition, nor subtraction, since that destroys its being a rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:73
verses.text: "By the same rule," i-e: by the same faith, within the same limits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:74
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:75
verses.text: "Brethren, be ye imitators of me, and mark them which so walk even as ye have us for an ensample".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:76
verses.text: He had said above, "beware of dogs," from such he had led them away; he brings them near to these whom they ought to imitate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:77
verses.text: If any one, saith he, wishes to imitate me, if any one wishes to walk the same road, let him take heed to them; though I am not present, ye know the manner of my walk, that is, my conduct in life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:78
verses.text: For not by words only did he teach, but by deeds too; as in the chorus, and the army, the rest must imitate the leader of the chorus or the army, and thus advance in good order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:79
verses.text: For it is possible that the order may be dissolved by sedition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:80
verses.text: The Apostles therefore were a type, and kept throughout a certain archetypal model.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:81
verses.text: Consider how entirely accurate their life was, so that they are proposed as an archetype and example, and as living laws.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:82
verses.text: For what was said in their writings, they manifested to all in their actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:83
verses.text: This is the best teaching; thus he will be able to carry on his disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:84
verses.text: But if he indeed speaks as a philosopher, yet in his actions doth the contrary, he is no longer a teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:85
verses.text: For mere verbal philosophy is easy even for the disciple: but there is need of that teaching and leading which comes of deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:86
verses.text: For this both makes the teacher to be reverenced, and prepares the disciple to yield obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:87
verses.text: How so? When one sees him delivering philosophy in words, he will say he commands impossibilities; that they are impossibilities, he himself is the first to show, who does not practice them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:88
verses.text: But if he sees his virtue fully carried out in action, he will no longer be able to speak thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:89
verses.text: Yet although the life of our teacher be careless, let us take heed to ourselves, and let us listen to the words of the prophet; "They shall be all taught of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:90
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:91
verses.text: liv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:92
verses.text: ) "And they shall teach no more every man his brother, saying, Know the Lord, for they shall all know me from the least of them to the greatest of them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:93
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:94
verses.text: xxxi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:95
verses.text: ) Hast thou a teacher who is not virtuous? Still thou hast Him who is truly a Teacher, whom alone thou shouldest call a Teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:96
verses.text: Learn from Him: He hath said, "Learn of Me, for I am meek".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:97
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:98
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:99
verses.text: ) Take not heed, then, to thy teacher, but to Him and to His lessons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:100
verses.text: Take thence thy examples, thou hast a most excellent model, to it conform thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:101
verses.text: There are innumerable models laid before thee in the Scriptures of virtuous lives; whichsoever thou wilt, come, and after the Master find it in the disciples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:102
verses.text: One hath shown forth through poverty, another through riches; for example, Elijah through poverty, Abraham through riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:103
verses.text: Go to that example, which thou esteemest most easy, most befitting thyself to practice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:104
verses.text: Again, one by marriage, the other by virginity; Abraham by marriage, the other by virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:105
verses.text: Follow whichever thou wilt: for both lead to heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:106
verses.text: One shone forth by fasting, as John, another without fasting, as Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:107
verses.text: Again, this latter had a care for his wife, his children, his daughters, his family, and possessed great wealth; the other possessed nothing but the garment of hair.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:108
verses.text: And why do I make mention of family, or wealth, or money, when it is possible that even one in a kingdom should lay hold on virtue, for the house of a king would be found more full of trouble than any private family.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:109
verses.text: David then shone forth in his kingdom; the purple and the diadem rendered him not at all remiss.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:110
verses.text: To another it was entrusted to preside over a whole people, I mean Moses, which was a more difficult task, for there the power was greater, whence the difficulty too became greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:111
verses.text: Thou hast seen men approved in wealth, thou hast seen them in poverty also, thou hast seen them in marriage, thou hast seen them in virginity too; on the contrary, behold some lost in marriage and in virginity, in wealth and in poverty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:112
verses.text: For example, many men have perished in marriage, as Samson, yet not from marriage, but from their own deliberate choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:113
verses.text: Likewise in virginity, as the five virgins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:114
verses.text: In wealth, as the rich man, who disregarded Lazarus: in poverty, innumerable poor men even now are lost.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:115
verses.text: In a kingdom, I can point to many who have perished, and in ruling the people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:116
verses.text: Wouldest thou see men saved in the rank of a soldier? there is Cornelius; and in the government of a household? there is the eunuch of the Ethiopian Queen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:117
verses.text: Thus is it universally.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:118
verses.text: If we use our wealth as is fit, nothing will destroy us; but if not, all things will destroy us, whether a kingdom, or poverty, or wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:119
verses.text: But nothing will have power to hurt the man, who keeps well awake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:120
verses.text: For tell me, was captivity any harm? None at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:121
verses.text: For consider, I pray thee, Joseph, who became a slave, and preserved his virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:122
verses.text: Consider Daniel, and the Three Children, who became captives, and how much the more they shone forth, for virtue shineth everywhere, is invincible, and nothing can put hindrances in its way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:123
verses.text: But why make I mention of poverty, and captivity, and slavery; and hunger, and sores, and grievous disease? For disease is more hard to endure than slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:124
verses.text: Such was Lazarus, such was Job, such was also Timothy, straitened by "often infirmities".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:125
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:126
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:127
verses.text: ) Thou seest that nothing can obtain the mastery over virtue; neither wealth, nor poverty, nor dominion, nor subjection, nor the preëminence in affairs, nor disease, nor contempt, nor abandonment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:128
verses.text: But having left all these things below, and upon the earth, it hastens towards Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:129
verses.text: Only let the soul be noble, and nought can hinder it from being virtuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:130
verses.text: For when he who works is in vigor, nothing external can hinder him; for as in the arts, when the artificer is experienced and persevering, and thoroughly acquainted with his art, if disease overtakes him, he still hath it; if he became poor, he still hath it; whether he hath his tools in his hand or hath them not, whether he works or worketh not, he loseth not at all his art: for the science of it is contained within him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:131
verses.text: Thus too the virtuous man, who is devoted to God, manifests his art, if you cast him into wealth, or if into poverty, if into disease, if into health, if into dishonor, if into great honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:132
verses.text: Did not the Apostles work in every state, "By glory and dishonor, by good report and evil report"? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:133
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:134
verses.text: ) This is an athlete, to be prepared for everything; for such is also the nature of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:135
verses.text: If thou sayest, I am not able to preside over many, I ought to lead a solitary life; thou offerest an insult to virtue, for it can make use of every state, and shine through all: only let it be in the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:136
verses.text: Is there a famine? or is there abundance? It shows forth its own strength, as Paul saith, "I know how to abound, and how to be in want".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:137
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:138
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:139
verses.text: ; Acts xxviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:140
verses.text: ) Was he required to work? He was not ashamed, but wrought two years.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:141
verses.text: Was hunger to be undergone? He sank not under it, nor wavered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:142
verses.text: Was death to be borne? He became not dejected, through all he exhibited his noble mind and art.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:143
verses.text: Him therefore let us imitate, and we shall have no cause of grief: for tell me, what will have power to grieve such an one? Nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:144
verses.text: As long as no one deprives us of this art, this will be the most blessed of all men, even in this life as well as in that to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:145
verses.text: For suppose the good man hath a wife and children, and riches, and great honor, with all these things he remaineth alike virtuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:146
verses.text: Take them away, and again in like sort he will be virtuous, neither overwhelmed by his misfortunes, nor puffed up by prosperity, but as a rock standeth equally unmoved in the raging sea and in calm, neither broken by the waves nor influenced at all by the calm, thus too the solid mind stands firm both in calm and in storm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:147
verses.text: And as little children, when sailing in a ship, are tossed about, whilst the pilot sits by, laughing and undisturbed, and delighted to see their confusion; thus too the soul which is truly wise, when all others are in confusion, or else are inopportunely smiling at any change of circumstance, sits unmoved, as it were, at the tiller and helm of piety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:148
verses.text: For tell me, what can disturb the pious soul? Can death? This is the beginning of a better life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:149
verses.text: Can poverty? This helps her on toward virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:150
verses.text: Can disease? She regards not its presence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:151
verses.text: She regards neither ease, nor affliction; for being beforehand with it, she hath afflicted herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:152
verses.text: Can dishonor? The world hath been crucified to her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:153
verses.text: Can the loss of children? She fears it not, when she is fully persuaded of the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:154
verses.text: What then can surprise her? None of all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:155
verses.text: Doth wealth elevate her? By no means, she knoweth that money is nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:156
verses.text: Doth glory? She hath been taught that "all the glory of man is as the flower of grass".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:157
verses.text: (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:158
verses.text: xl.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:159
verses.text: ) Doth luxury? She hath heard Paul say, "She that giveth herself to pleasure is dead while she liveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:160
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:161
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:162
verses.text: ) Since then she is neither inflamed nor cramped, what can equal such health as this?  Other souls, meanwhile, are not such, but change more frequently than the sea, or the cameleon, so that thou hast great cause to smile, when thou seest the same man at one time laughing, at another weeping, at one time full of care, at another beyond measure relaxed and languid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:163
verses.text: For this cause Paul saith, "Be not fashioned according to this world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:164
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:165
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:166
verses.text: ) For we are citizens of heaven, where there is no turning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:167
verses.text: Prizes which change not are held out to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:168
verses.text: Let us make manifest this our citizenship, let us thence already receive our good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:169
verses.text: But why do we cast ourselves into the Euripus, into tempest, into storm, into foam? Let us be in calm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:170
verses.text: It all depends not on wealth, nor on poverty, nor honor, nor dishonor, nor on sickness, nor on health, nor on weakness, but on our own soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:171
verses.text: If it is solid, and well-instructed in the science of virtue, all things will be easy to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 13:172
verses.text: Even hence it will already behold its rest, and that quiet harbor, and, on its departure, will there attain innumerable good things, the which may we all attain, by the grace and love of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, to the Father, together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, dominion, honor, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:1
verses.text: Homily XIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:2
verses.text: Philippians iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:3
verses.text: –  "For many walk, of whom I told you often, and now tell you even weeping, that they are the enemies of the cross of Christ: whose end is perdition, whose god is the belly, and whose glory is in their shame, who mind earthly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:4
verses.text: For our citizenship is in heaven; from whence also we wait for a Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ: who shall fashion anew the body of our humiliation, that it may be conformed to the body of his glory, according to the working whereby He is able even to subject all things unto Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:5
verses.text: Nothing is so incongruous in a Christian, and foreign to his character, as to seek ease and rest; and to be engrossed with the present life is foreign to our profession and enlistment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:6
verses.text: Thy Master was crucified, and dost thou seek ease? Thy Master was pierced with nails, and dost thou live delicately? Do these things become a noble soldier? Wherefore Paul saith, "Many walk, of whom I told you often, and now tell you even weeping, that they are the enemies of the cross of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:7
verses.text: Since there were some who made a pretense of Christianity, yet lived in ease and luxury, and this is contrary to the Cross: therefore he thus spoke.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:8
verses.text: For the cross belongs to a soul at its post for the fight, longing to die, seeking nothing like ease, whilst their conduct is of the contrary sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:9
verses.text: So that even if they say, they are Christ's, still they are as it were enemies of the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:10
verses.text: For did they love the Cross, they would strive to live the crucified life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:11
verses.text: Was not thy Master hung upon the tree? Do thou otherwise imitate Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:12
verses.text: Crucify thyself, though no one crucify thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:13
verses.text: Crucify thyself, not that thou mayest slay thyself, God forbid, for that is a wicked thing, but as Paul said, "The world hath been crucified unto me and I unto the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:14
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:15
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:16
verses.text: ) If thou lovest thy Master, die His death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:17
verses.text: Learn how great is the power of the Cross; how many good things it hath achieved, and doth still: how it is the safety of our life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:18
verses.text: Through it all things are done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:19
verses.text: Baptism is through the Cross, for we must receive that seal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:20
verses.text: The laying on of hands is through the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:21
verses.text: If we are on journeys, if we are at home, wherever we are, the Cross is a great good, the armor of salvation, a shield which cannot be beaten down, a weapon to oppose the devil; thou bearest the Cross when thou art at enmity with him, not simply when thou sealest thyself by it, but when thou sufferest the things belonging to the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:22
verses.text: Christ thought fit to call our sufferings by the name of the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:23
verses.text: As when he saith, "Except a man take up his cross and follow Me" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:24
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:25
verses.text: ), i-e: except he be prepared to die.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:26
verses.text: But these being base, and lovers of life, and lovers of their bodies, are enemies of the Cross.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:27
verses.text: And every one, who is a friend of luxury, and of present safety, is an enemy of that Cross in which Paul makes his boast: which he embraces, with which he desires to be incorporated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:28
verses.text: As when he saith, "I am crucified unto the world, and the world unto me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:29
verses.text: But here he saith, "I now tell you weeping".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:30
verses.text: Wherefore? Because the evil was urgent, because such deserve tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:31
verses.text: Of a truth the luxurious are worthy of tears, who make fat that which is thrown about them, I mean the body, and take no thought of that soul which must give account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:32
verses.text: Behold thou livest delicately, behold thou art drunken, to-day and to-morrow, ten years, twenty, thirty, fifty, a hundred, which is impossible; but if thou wilt, let us suppose it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:33
verses.text: What is the end? What is the gain? Nought at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:34
verses.text: Doth it not then deserve tears, and lamentations, to lead such a life; God hath brought us into this course, that He may crown us, and we take our departure without doing any noble action.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:35
verses.text: Wherefore Paul weepeth, where others laugh, and live in pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:36
verses.text: So sympathetic is he: such thought taketh he for all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:37
verses.text: "Whose god," saith he, "is the belly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:38
verses.text: For this have they a God! That is, "let us eat and drink!" Dost thou see, how great an evil luxury is? to some their wealth, and to others their belly is a god.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:39
verses.text: Are not these too idolaters, and worse than the common? And their "glory is in their shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:40
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:41
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:42
verses.text: ) Some say it is circumcision.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:43
verses.text: I think not so, but this is its meaning, they make a boast of those things, of which they ought to be ashamed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:44
verses.text: It is a fearful thing to do shameful actions; yet to do them, and be ashamed, is only half so dreadful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:45
verses.text: But where a man even boasts himself of them, it is excessive senselessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:46
verses.text: Do these words apply to them alone? And do those who are here present escape the charge? And will no one have account to render of these things? Does no one make a god of his belly, or glory in his shame? I wish, earnestly I wish, that none of these charges lay against us, and that I did not know any one involved in what I have said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:47
verses.text: But I fear lest the words have more reference to us than to the men of those times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:48
verses.text: For when one consumes his whole life in drinking and reveling, and expends some small trifle on the poor, whilst he consumes the larger portion on his belly, will not these words with justice apply to him? No words are more apt to call attention, or more cutting in reproof, than these: "Whose god is the belly, whose glory is in their shame".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:49
verses.text: And who are these? They, he says, who mind earthly things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:50
verses.text: "Let us build houses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:51
verses.text: Where, I ask? On the earth, they answer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:52
verses.text: Let us purchase farms; on the earth again: let us obtain power; again on the earth: let us gain glory; again on the earth: let us enrich ourselves; all these things are on the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:53
verses.text: These are they, whose god is their belly; for if they have no spiritual thoughts, but have all their possessions here, and mind these things, with reason have they their belly for their god, in saying, "Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:54
verses.text: And about thy body, thou grievest, tell me, that it is of earth, though thus thou art not at all injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:55
verses.text: But thy soul thou draggest down to the earth, when thou oughtest to render even thy body spiritual; for thou mayest, if thou wilt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:56
verses.text: Thou hast received a belly, that thou mayest feed, not distend it, that thou mayest have the mastery over it, not have it as mistress over thee: that it may minister to thee for the nourishment of the other parts, not that thou mayest minister to it, not that thou mayest exceed limits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:57
verses.text: The sea, when it passes its bounds, doth not work so many evils, as the belly doth to our body, together with our soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:58
verses.text: The former overfloweth all the earth, the latter all the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:59
verses.text: Put moderation for a boundary to it, as God hath put the sand for the sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:60
verses.text: Then if its waves arise, and rage furiously, rebuke it, with the power which is in thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:61
verses.text: See how God hath honored thee, that thou mightest imitate Him, and thou wilt not; but thou seest the belly overflowing, destroying and overwhelming thy whole nature, and darest not to restrain or moderate it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:62
verses.text: "Whose God," he saith, "is their belly".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:63
verses.text: Let us see how Paul served God: let us see how gluttons serve their belly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:64
verses.text: Do not they undergo ten thousand such deaths? do not they fear to disobey whatever it orders? do not they minister impossibilities to it? Are not they worse than slaves? "But our citizenship," says he, "is in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:65
verses.text: Let us not then seek for ease here; there do we shine, where also our citizenship is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:66
verses.text: "From whence also," saith he, "we wait for a Saviour," the Lord Jesus Christ: "who shall fashion anew the body of our humiliation, that it may be conformed to the body of his glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:67
verses.text: By little and little he hath carried us up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:68
verses.text: He saith, "From Heaven" and "Our Saviour," showing, from the place and from the Person, the dignity of the subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:69
verses.text: "Who shall fashion anew the body of our humiliation," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:70
verses.text: The body now suffereth many things: it is bound with chains, it is scourged, it suffereth innumerable evils; but the body of Christ suffered the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:71
verses.text: This, then, he hinted at when he said, "That it may be conformed to the body of his glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:72
verses.text: Wherefore the body is the same, but putteth on incorruption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:73
verses.text: "Shall fashion anew".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:74
verses.text: Wherefore the fashion is different; or perchance he has spoken figuratively of the change.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:75
verses.text: He saith, "the body of our humiliation," because it is now humbled, subject to destruction, to pain, because it seemeth to be worthless, and to have nothing beyond that of other animals.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:76
verses.text: "That it may be conformed to the body of his glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:77
verses.text: What? shall this our body be fashioned like unto Him, who sitteth at the right hand of the Father, to Him who is worshiped by the Angels, before whom do stand the incorporeal Powers, to Him who is above all rule and power, and might? If then the whole world were to take up weeping and lament for those who have fallen from this hope, could it worthily lament? because, when a promise is given us of our body being made like to Him, it still departs with the demons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:78
verses.text: I care not for hell henceforth; whatever can be said, having fallen from so great glory, now and henceforth consider hell to be nothing to this falling away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:79
verses.text: What sayest thou, O Paul? To be made like unto Him? Yes, he answereth; then, lest you should disbelieve, he addeth a reason; "According to the working whereby He is able even to subject all things unto Himself".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:80
verses.text: He hath power, saith he, to subject all things unto Himself, wherefore also destruction and death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:81
verses.text: Or rather, He doth this also with the same power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:82
verses.text: For tell me, which requireth the greater power, to subject demons, and Angels, and Archangels, and Cherubim, and Seraphim, or to make the body incorruptible and immortal? The latter certainly much more than the former; he showed forth the greater works of His power, that you might believe these too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:83
verses.text: Wherefore, though ye see these men rejoicing, and honored, yet stand firm, be not offended at them, be not moved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:84
verses.text: These our hopes are sufficient to raise up even the most sluggish and indolent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:85
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:86
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:87
verses.text: ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:88
verses.text: "Wherefore," saith he, "my brethren, beloved and longed for, my joy and crown, so stand fast in the Lord, my beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:89
verses.text: "So".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:90
verses.text: How? Unmoved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:91
verses.text: See how he addeth praise after exhortation, "my joy and my crown," not simply joy but glory too, not simply glory but my crown too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:92
verses.text: Which glory nought can equal, since it is the crown of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:93
verses.text: "So stand fast in the Lord, my beloved," i-e: in the hope of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:94
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:96
verses.text: "I exhort Euodia, and exhort Syntyche, to be of the same mind in the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:97
verses.text: Yea, I beseech thee also, true yokefellow, help these women".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:98
verses.text: Some say Paul here exhorts his own wife; but it is not so, but some other woman, or the husband of one of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:99
verses.text: "Help these women, for they labored with me in the Gospel, with Clement also, and the rest of my fellow-workers whose names are in the book of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:100
verses.text: Seest thou how great a testimony he beareth to their virtue? For as Christ saith to his Apostles, "Rejoice not that the spirits are subject to you, but rejoice that your names are written in the book of life" (Luke x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:101
verses.text: ); so Paul testifieth to them, saying, "whose names are in the book of life".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:102
verses.text: These women seem to me to be the chief of the Church which was there, and he commendeth them to some notable man whom he calls his "yokefellow," to whom perchance he was wont to commend them, as to a fellow-worker, and fellow-soldier, and brother, and companion, as he doth in the Epistle to the Romans, when he saith, "I commend unto you Phebe our sister, who is a servant of the Church that is at Cenchrea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:103
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:104
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:105
verses.text: ) "Yokefellow;" either some brother of theirs, or a husband of hers; as if he had said, Now thou art a true brother, now a true husband, because thou hast become a Member.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:106
verses.text: "For they labored with me in the Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:107
verses.text: This protection came from home, not from friendship, but for good deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:108
verses.text: "Labored with me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:109
verses.text: What sayest thou? Did women labor with thee? Yes, he answereth, they too contributed no small portion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:110
verses.text: Although many were they who wrought together with him, yet these women also acted with him amongst the many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:111
verses.text: The Churches then were no little edified, for many good ends are gained where they who are approved, be they men, or be they women, enjoy from the rest such honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:112
verses.text: For in the first place the rest were led on to a like zeal; in the second place, they also gained by the respect shown; and thirdly, they made those very persons more zealous and earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:113
verses.text: Wherefore thou seest that Paul hath everywhere a care for this, and commendeth such men for consideration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:114
verses.text: As he saith in the Epistle to the Corinthians: "Who are the first-fruits of Achaia," ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:115
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:116
verses.text: ) Some say that the word "yokefellow," (Syzygus,) is a proper name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:117
verses.text: Well, what? Whether it be so, or no, we need not accurately enquire, but observe that he gives his orders, that these women should enjoy much protection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:118
verses.text: All we have, saith he, is in the heavens, our Saviour, our city, whatever a man can name: "whence," saith he, "we wait for a Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:119
verses.text: And this is an act of His kindness and love toward man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:120
verses.text: He Himself again cometh to us, he doth not drag us thither, but takes us, and so departs with us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:121
verses.text: And this is a mark of great honor; for if He came to us when we were enemies, much rather doth He now when we are become friends.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:122
verses.text: He doth not commit this to the Angels, nor to servants, but Himself cometh to call us to His royal mansion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:123
verses.text: See, we also "shall be caught up in the clouds" ( Thess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:124
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:125
verses.text: ), doing him honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:126
verses.text: Who then is to be found "the faithful and wise servant"? Who are they that are deemed worthy of such good things? How miserable are those who fail! For if we were forever to weep, should we do aught worthy of the occasion? For were you to make mention of hells innumerable, you would name nothing equal to that pain which the soul sustaineth, when all the world is in confusion, when the trumpets are sounding, when the Angels are rushing forward, the first, then the second, then the third, then ten thousand ranks, are pouring forth upon the earth; then the Cherubim, (and many are these and infinite;) the Seraphim; when He Himself is coming, with His ineffable glory; when those meet Him, who had gone to gather the elect into the midst; when Paul and his companions, and all who in his time had been approved, are crowned, are proclaimed aloud, are honored by the King, before all His heavenly host.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:127
verses.text: For if hell did not exist, how fearful a thing it is, that the one part should be honored, and the other dishonored! Hell, I confess, is intolerable, yea, very intolerable, but more intolerable than it is the loss of the Kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:128
verses.text: Consider; if any king, or the son of a king, having taken his departure, and been successful in innumerable wars, and become the object of admiration, should with his army entire, return to any city, in his chariot, with his trophies, with his innumerable ranks of golden shields, with his spearmen, his body-guard all about him, whilst the whole city was adorned with crowns, whilst all the rulers of the world accompanied him, and all the soldiery of foreign nations followed him as captives, then praefects, satraps, and in the presence of all the rulers, and all that splendor, he should receive the citizens who meet him, and kiss them, and stretch forth his hand, and give them freedom of access, and converse with them, all standing around, as with friends, and tell them that all that journey was undertaken for their sake, and should lead them into his palace, and give them a share of it, even if the rest should not be punished, to how great punishment would not this be equal? But if in the case of men it were a bitter thing to fall away from this glory, much more is it so with God, when all the heavenly Powers are present with the King, when the demons, bound, and bowing down their heads, and the devil himself is led along in chains, and all military force that opposeth itself, when the Powers of the heavens, when He Himself, cometh upon the clouds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:129
verses.text: Believe me, I am not even able to finish my words, from the grief which lays hold of my soul at this relation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:130
verses.text: Consider of how great glory we shall be deprived, when it is in our power not to be deprived of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:131
verses.text: For this is the misery, that we suffer these things, when it is in our power not to suffer them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:132
verses.text: When he receiveth the one part and leadeth them to His Father in heaven, and rejecteth the other, whom Angels take and drag against their will, weeping, and hanging down their heads, to the fire of hell, when they have first been made a spectacle to the whole world, what grief, think you, is there? Let us then make haste, while there is time, and take great thought of our own salvation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:133
verses.text: How many things have we to say like the rich man? If any one would now suffer us, we would take counsel of the things that are profitable! But no one doth suffer us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:134
verses.text: And that we shall so say, is clear, not from him alone, but from many others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:135
verses.text: And that you may learn this, how many men have been in fevers, and said, if we recover, we shall never again fall into the same state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:136
verses.text: Many such words we shall then say, but we shall be answered as the rich man was, that there is a gulf, that we have received our good things here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:137
verses.text: (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:139
verses.text: ) Let us groan then, I entreat you, bitterly, rather let us not only groan, but pursue virtue too; let us lament now, for salvation, that we may not then lament in vain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:140
verses.text: Let us weep now, and not weep then, at our evil lot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:141
verses.text: This weeping is of virtue, that of unprofitable repentance; let us afflict ourselves now, that we may not then; for it is not the same thing to be afflicted here and there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:142
verses.text: Here, thou art afflicted for a little time, or rather thou dost not perceive thy affliction, knowing that thou art afflicted for thy good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:143
verses.text: But there, the affliction is more bitter, because it is not in hope, nor for any escape, but without limit, and throughout.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:144
verses.text: But may we all be freed from this, and obtain remission.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:145
verses.text: But let us pray and be diligent, that we may obtain the remission.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:146
verses.text: Let us be diligent, I entreat; for if we are diligent, we prevail even through our prayer: if we pray earnestly, God grants our request; but if we neither ask Him, nor do earnestly aught of this sort, nor work, how is it possible that we should ever succeed? By sleeping? Not at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:147
verses.text: For it is much if even by running, and stretching forth, and being conformed to His death, as Paul said, we shall be able to succeed, not to say sleeping.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:148
verses.text: "If by any means I may attain," saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:149
verses.text: But if Paul said, "If by any means I may attain," what shall we say? For it is not possible by sleeping to accomplish even worldly business, not to say spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:150
verses.text: By sleeping, not even from friends can anything be received, far less from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:151
verses.text: Not even fathers honor them who sleep, far less doth God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:152
verses.text: Let us labor for a little time, that we may have rest for ever.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:153
verses.text: We must at all events be afflicted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:154
verses.text: If we are not afflicted here, it awaits us there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 14:155
verses.text: Why choose we not to be afflicted here, that there we may have rest, and obtain the unspeakable blessings, in Christ Jesus, with whom, to the Father together with the Holy Spirit, be glory, power, and honor, now and ever, world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:1
verses.text: Homily XIV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:2
verses.text: Philippians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:3
verses.text: –  "Rejoice in the Lord alway: again I will say, Rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:4
verses.text: Let your forbearance be known unto all men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:5
verses.text: The Lord is at hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:6
verses.text: In nothing be anxious; but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:7
verses.text: And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall guard your hearts and your thoughts through Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:8
verses.text: "Blessed are they that mourn," and "woe unto them that laugh" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:9
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:10
verses.text: ; Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:11
verses.text: ), saith Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:12
verses.text: How then saith Paul, "Rejoice in the Lord alway"? "Woe to them that laugh," said Christ, the laughter of this world which ariseth from the things which are present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:13
verses.text: He blessed also those that mourn, not simply for the loss of relatives, but those who are pricked at heart, who mourn their own faults, and take count of their own sins, or even those of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:14
verses.text: This joy is not contrary to that grief, but from that grief it too is born.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:15
verses.text: For he who grieveth for his own faults, and confesseth them, rejoiceth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:16
verses.text: Moreover, it is possible to grieve for our own sins, and yet to rejoice in Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:17
verses.text: Since then they were afflicted by their sufferings, "for to you it is given not only to believe in him, but also to suffer for him" (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:18
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:19
verses.text: ), therefore he saith, "Rejoice in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:20
verses.text: For this can but mean, If you exhibit such a life that you may rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:21
verses.text: Or when your communion with God is not hindered, rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:22
verses.text: Or else the word "in" may stand for "with": as if he had said, with the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:23
verses.text: "Alway; again I will say, Rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:24
verses.text: These are the words of one who brings comfort; as, for example, he who is in God rejoiceth alway.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:25
verses.text: Yea though he be afflicted, yea whatever he may suffer, such a man alway rejoiceth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:26
verses.text: Hear what Luke saith, that "they returned from the presence of the Council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to be scourged for His name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:27
verses.text: (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:28
verses.text: ) If scourging and bonds, which seem to be the most grievous of all things, bring forth joy, what else will be able to produce grief in us?  "Again I will say, Rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:29
verses.text: Well hath he repeated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:30
verses.text: For since the nature of the things brought forth grief, he shows by repeating, that they should by all means rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:31
verses.text: "Let your forbearance be known unto all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:32
verses.text: He said above, "Whose god is the belly, and whose glory is in their shame," and that they "mind earthly things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:33
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:34
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Philippians 15:35
verses.text: ) It was probable that they would be at enmity with the wicked; he therefore exhorted them to have nothing in common with them, but to use them with all forbearance, and that not only their brethren, but also their enemies and opposers.
